reviewText:
Early Access Review

So this is the squeal to the Dungeon Defenders series. let's start with pros and cons and give it an equal side.
Pros
+ LOOT, this is the life force of the game, there is SO much awesome loot.

+ Fun game-play with multiple classes you can build or jump on you hero and smack things with a sword, or other weapons.

+ Players can be creative with the classes and builds, so you can play your way.

+ Large multi player base, Lot's of people playing and it's easy finding a group of people to play with for anything.

+ Don't like Multi Player? With one of the recent patches/changes the game has been re-balanced for single players so you're not punished for wanted to play alone!

+ A daily quest system that can hold 3 quests! This mean each day a quest will be given, the game will hold 3 for you so you don't have to play every day.

+ Don't like a daily quest because it doesn't fit your play style? Or maybe you just don't wanna do it? Then you can re-roll!

+ The monthly quest system introduces major rewards making them feel they are really worth doing.

+ With how the new item system works alot of gear now introduces abilities and effects to your towers will gives way for more
interesting play, frost towers being able to buff the damage of other towers, or having your harpoons explode on each and every target as they pierce the horde of monsters.

+ Many maps and modes to play on, you can hit the hard maps for the godly gear or play the normal maps to relax and just bank up your coins and pets.

+ Did I mention pets?!! You can find eggs during matches and then take them back to the tavern to be hatched! Pets can do multiple things for you from giving you a boost in stats, damaging the monsters you fight to having a an ability that assists you or damages enemies and there are lots of abilities.

+ NO PAY TO WIN  at all Trendy has made it their goal to do this, all micro-transactions are skins for pets,heros and (planned) Tower skins! So towers will look different and have different animations, oh and bags let's talk about bags.

+ Trendy has recently introduced a system where you can now Auto gather to specific bags and auto sort with them to keep your cache of loot neat and tidy! You can also customize your bags icons/names to what you want making organization a breeze.

+ It may not seem like it, but the developers read every scrap of feed back people offer for the game, the forums are incredibly active and the developers do listen and will partake in the forums and chats, sometimes you may even run in to a white named person in a game and play with em!

+ Every week they have a Developer cast on twitch to show case some of the new features, talk to the players, get feed back and improve the game, they will also answer various questions from chat and forums. The developers are really active in the community.

+ Vibrant art style full of colors and awesome effects.

Cons every game has em.
- The loved lobby system is no longer, we can no longer scroll through a list and see a list of players playing what maps and what levels they may be or modes they may be running, you just kinda go in to a tavern and go to the war map and join a game based on map and mode, and if there are others playing it will put you with them, if there isent any then it will create a new game for you.

- No offline single player, this will effect some more then others.

- The RNG in this game is heavy, some times you just want that one item with those beastly tower stats and all that drops is hero skill gear.

-The game is currently in alpha, so bugs and other issues are to be expected as well as changes, this may include wipes or changes to the core of the game, so once you get a feel for the game you can lose everything you thought you knew due to the changes,

-The pet skins the only negative thing about this is the fact you have to buy and apply a skin before knowing what rarity the pet will be so its a gamble and not a very good one.

-There are some Anti Troll mechanics put in to place for the actual game, but while in the tavern they have almost free reign(can always make a private tavern to bypass this though)

-4 classes at this time there are only 4 classes in the game so options can feel limited, however trendy has said they will release more heros(free)

- NPC shop keepers kinda have nothing useful for sale, all the good stuff is out there in the monsters gullets! So get out there and get chopping-

-Pet hatching time is a bit long, as of now it's 8 hours for a single pet to hatch, that's real time, there is talk from the devs that the time may change soon.

- Unlike DD1 the mana is sparse so you have to play more carefully so no more maxing out all dem towers and seeing all the pretty stars.

- The current lack of content you can play on multiple maps on multiple modes which is really fun, but I just wish there was more raw content, I know they are working on it though.

Over All I would recommend this game, please remember this game is in alpha, so if that bothers you then you may wanna wait or go watch some game play on twitch or youtube before you decide, if you're like myself and don't mind a few bumps here and there and get to watch the game grow then jump on it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

17.10.15 - I'm recommending it now and will replace the review below once it gets out of early access.
--
I loved Dungeon Defenders 1, I even loved the nightmare-gear gap that a lot of people struggled with.
This is my opinion about DD2 on Day1/2.

DD2, out of the box and eventhough it still is in early access, is a heavily gated experience. It forces you through an abyssmal grind while isolating you from the rest of the player base the higher you go. Personal skill isn't rewarded, but how many times you attempted a mission. You can win a campaign map but it doesn't unlock the next one - something I have never seen before - it's behind a ridiculous mechanic where you have to grind previous maps over and over for XP until the next one unlocks even if you wouldn't have any problems winning the next ones. You can't even attempt harder maps or harder difficulties. I know a fair deal of grinding, but I don't understand why a game won't let you progress even if you conquered all the maps you've previously played. The whole war table thing doesn't make any sense and should be abolished because a system where players are put into tiers is dumb.

A lot of my fun in DD1 was figuring out placements, but it seems it has been completely thrown out of the window here.
If you're too strong, the game just downscales all of your stats/towers and always attempts to put you on the verge of barely winning. It's good if you want that sort of challenge, but the game also forces you through this item progression grind. In DD1 you could perfectly well do maps below Nightmare if you knew how to play. You would also believe that finishing on normal would unlock harder difficulties for the map - it doesn't, you have to accumulate a ton of XP until the game decides you're up for 'hard' mode on specific maps. It doesn't make any sense, considering that the game limits your access of maps depending on your level. Most of the times you will not be able to even replay levels in the next tier. So the progression system actually regresses the options you should have available. WHY?

I think this is all an effort to stop people from twinking and powerleveling, because otherwise selling gold or other services isn't going to be profitable in the future if it wasn't obstructed. Which is probably going to be a big deal because even upgrading your gear requires a lot of gold to a point where you waste more gold on a level 1 upgrade than you possibly get from finishing a map. That's completely bonkers. Though there are a few silver linings.

The PC version is well done, as opposed to DD1 which struggled with a lot of port problems. Eventhough there are a lot of interface options, it's still lacking a way to disable ally health and enable that tower health is always being shown or at least if it's on low health. I like the concept of the chests at the end and that you don't have to complete all waves to still get a reward. Actually between finishing or failing a map there is very little incentive, aside from the possible higher rarity loot at the end and slightly more xp depending on the wave you were. All that matters in the end is that you've attempted it and you get your fair share of a reward. It turns everyone into a winner, behind a heavily grind/gated based mechanic.


I can't recommend this to anyone who loved DD1, as it is right now. Wait for it to come out in 1-2 years and hope that they didn't turn this into a game on-par with a mindless cow clicker and with more substance instead. Also be aware that this game can only be played if you are online, it's basically a mmo.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Here, I am going to explain the Dungeon Defenders PC lineup to you in TL;DR fashion:

DD1 (Dungeon Defenders - that's the first one)
Base game is best value for money, boasts great replayability and lots of tower defence & hack 'n slashing fun and great to get your feet wet.

DLC rather steep: £5 will get you a single map and a challenge, slightly less may get you a single character, less than that may get you a costume.
DLC price total is triple that of the original game.
DLC controversy due to not only being overpriced but creating a divide in playerbase (People with DLC's couldn't play those without DLC's) and a heavy power creep in new gear making the late game shamefully easy for veterans and causing many newer players to hit a wall they could not surpass (say goodbye to winning any online PvP challenges!).
Hacking became an issue - as of current has mostly died off though abuse of Steam Workshop has created massive Mana (Money) / EXP / Hacked Gear generation maps, as tempting as it is, don't do it. You'll ruin the game for yourself.

Advise people interested in the series to start here - buy full package (That means game + DLC) on Steam Sale, Indie Bundle or otherwise where cheapest.

DDE (Dungeon Defenders Eternity - the worst one)
A rereleased version of DD1 - purported as the 'definitive' version, which is basically a glorified DD2 beta - testing out features of the new engine for the recent DD2 release, I'm not even going to list the features here - they are so insubstantial to what was lost and you just shouldn't bother even considering buying this one.

No Local Multiplayer.
No Steam Workshop.
Always (forcibly) online, with god awful connection - just trust me on this one.
Ingame store with microtransactions despite already having paid for the bloody thing.
This is the MOBILE PHONE version of the game ported to PC.

Would not recommend to my worst enemy.

DD2 (Dungeon Defenders 2 - What you're actually here for)
I was incredibly wary of DD2 upon hearing of its release - having read other reviews I made the decision to take the plunge into buying Early Access, here's what I think, take it as you will:

~ Larger emphasis on combat, for better or worse depending on your own personal tastes: each class has had their number of unique skills increased from DD1 from 2 -> 3, however the total types of towers each has fell from 5 -> 4.

+ Combat, thankfully, feels better for the most part.
+ Animations are more lively than the previous game.
+ Skill spheres are a pretty cool concept.
+ Microtransactions ingame grant no play bonuses to those that pay for them (ergo: no pay-to-win), and Trendy have made the promise to keep to this.

- ...But damn, ingame purchases are expensive: for a single Monk Ninja costume it will cost you 1200 gems - the equivalent of $12.
- Characters are normalized across the board: no colour customization at the time of writing and the game has lost the RPG character development in favour of gear being the sole provider of stat boosts, along with Skill Spheres, which, depending on the size can increase stats by variable amounts or completely change the way a facet of your character works (such as a tower's mode of fire) though there aren't many of these at the time of writing either.
- Characters feel somewhat imbalanced - Monk and Huntress have great synergy together (for those who have/n't played: Geyser Traps and Electric Aura can stun & damage for days) which writes off the viability of the Squire (my class) and the Apprentice - which is a shame because while tower synergy is really cool, the current designs indicate little synergy outside of the Monk-Huntress combo I mentioned - making them more popular for people who know of it.
- Maps can feel claustrophobic compared to the previous game (we're only counting DD1 as a comparative: screw DDE).
- It's always online - you can host a Private Game and play by yourself, but good luck: this game was NOT meant for soloing, and is significantly harder to do so alone, considering prior shady practices of Trendy in and outside of DD (look them up, and need I mention DDE again), it's worrying that once this game - as an MMO - gets out of Early Access, they may simply drop it if the money isn't good enough anymore, meaning people who have invested into the game will flat out no longer be able to play it (which is my biggest overall apprehension - but it can't really be avoided).

Final Thoughts
As surprising as it was, despite my skepticism I still really enjoyed (and am currently enjoying) my time playing DD2, and was impressed for what it offered, being pre-alpha.

Do buy if you:

Are crazy for another blast of Dungeon Defending goodness.
Have tried it elsewhere and like it and can see yourself playing it in future (It's good value for money!).
Or alternatively you're one of many Steam-goers who just likes wasting money on games they'll never likely play.

Don't buy if you:

Have never played DD1: try that first and THEN consider this game.
Didn't like DD1 - at the time of writing it still currently stands as the best of the  three  two Dungeon Defenders games.
Felt that stat allocation and creation of character builds was vital to your enjoyment of DD1 - as an MMO this game currently just doesn't boast the allowance for such individuality and feels homogenized as a result.
Are on the fence on the matter - you can always wait rather than waste your student loan on an eventual F2P MMO.
Don't have enough money in your Bank Account/Steam Wallet/Steam Point Card because Steam will refuse to let you purchase a game you can't afford and you'll just look like an idiot.

All in all, I actually really enjoyed myself, and got the Collector's Edition on top of that to show my support: don't let me down Trendy.

Edit: Steam completely destroyed my formatting for some reason.

Early Access Review

alright so my problem with this game is simple, in order to unlock a new hero such as the abyss lord you need 10,000 defender medals.

now the best way to farm those woud be betsy on nightmare 4 wich give you about 25 medals every 20 mins,
so that woud be 25 x 3 = 75 per hour not to mention it requires some good gear wich might also take you a few hours to get.

so in order to buy a 10,000 hero you woud need 133 hours of straight up farming, now ofc's there are the daily's wich provide you some boost but. you woud also want a hero slot for addional hero's  wich will cost you 2,000 medals also let's not forget the large spheres that you need in order to optimize you new hero wich will also end up in about 1000 - 2500 medals

so over all you need a good few 150+ hours of farming medals in order to get 1 hero decked out. exluding daily and monthly mission, they woud indeed reduce it allot but still it woud remain above 100 hours.

it's simply to much medal farming it's clear they need the money but i do not think this is the best way of obtaining it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

EDIT:
Made my points clearer, and fixed some of my horrendous grammar.
EDIT 2:
I've added some more points.

DISCLAIMER:
I have some 200~ hours as of the time of writing because I've been mindlessly farming stuff I hope to trade some day, not because there's actually this much content.

Please read this, Trendy, for the sake of your game.
Trendy saw, read and responded. I'm impressed. I just hope you'll take some of this to heart.

TL;DR at the bottom.

It is a good game, right now a downgrade from DD1 sure, but a good game still.  I'd like nothing more than to change my review to a positive one, but It has some concerning flaws that makes me want to discourage the purchase of any dlc/gems until they are fixed though, especially since Trendy seems more intent on making more skins rather than adding content or fixing bugs. The game is still in alpha with alpha amounts of content, and its making me kinda nervous when Trendy is saying they're planning on releasing the game this year.

They are as follows:

Loot and loot customization/upgrading is completely shallow compared to DD1. Items have class specific traits though that make 99% of the loot you find without said stats useless, making it harder (read: not in a good way) to progress. In dd1 you could just grab near any piece of decent loot and upgrade the ♥♥♥♥ out of it. All gear say for some legendaries are now trash. There's no real achievement to getting legendary pets either, considering a single onslaught run up to 15 gets me on average at least one.
Getting good loot used to be such a rush...

Upgrading your loot nets you about one items worth of the single stat you want, whereas in DD1, depending on how much mana you had and the upgrade levels, the benefits could be massive. This makes upgrading to get a grand total of 300 tower health split across all your items such a letdown.


The game has general lag and disconnecting issues for many players, even while playing singleplayer(!).

The game runs over 60 fps, mostly, but never 144 fps, even on my gtx 970 and i7-4770k... And suffers frequent fps drops in certain areas, like the tavern. For a game on the Unreal engine it should run better.

There are few maps, most of which not really that interesting, and no fun challenges like in the previous game (incursion is just more mobs and minibosses, onslaught is near pointless to do for anything other than golden egg farming). This, combined with the loot problems doesn't exactly encourage the progression into the higher nightmares.

Experience gain is really weird. Out of the gamemodes and all the difficulties, the most efficient way to earn exp as of the time of writing is to just repeat liferoot freeplay hard over and over. Nightmare 1 dragonfall gives you about 100k exp, while liferoot hard gives you 180k.

No trading (yet?) and no playershops. This was a really big part of the previous game for me and many of my friends who enjoyed DD1. Customizing your very own tavern with your items and having your achievements on display was a really neat feature.

They keep using the words Play [the hero] your way" in the devstreams

As of early access. I have to give this one a thumbsdown and here's why.

First of all the positive:

Graphics - Game looks a lot better than the previous in my opinion. It  doesn't look blocky, It looks smooth. Lighting's quite impressive and it is also colourful which is what I like about the game. Not to mention they actually manage to put a little bit of realness(if that's a word) to it by making trees sway, leaves on trees move and grass and other plantation have animation as well.

Items - The item actually looks better in terms of quality. Like my squire for example I have a common, epic and mythical sword. By looking at the three the higher the quality the better than look of the weapon, I mean I played DD1 and a lot of the time, I prefer the looks of my supreme quality items than my ultimate quality ones which doesn't make sense since you want to make the better quality to look more epic, right?

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Edited, yet again.

I'm not sure where to begin at the moment. Part of me loves this game and wants it to succeed so very much, and part of me is very bitter at the moment.

I'll try my best to explain why, and you can make the call based on that, whether or not it's worth your time.

Leveling, and getting to max level is not bad at all and in fact if that's all you intend to do, I say play it, you have nothing to lose really and things are quite fun especially if you have multiple friends to play with. The art is well done, the gameplay is quite smooth and it's a fun casual relaxed experience which I think anyone can enjoy really.

Here's where it starts to get gritty, and you'll either hate it or love it for the most part. Once you're maxed level, and you want to start to improve your gear, there's really not much left to be desired. You'll play the same maps you were playing, only with higher HP monsters and higher damage. And you'll not see any variation from that at all. Allow me to reiterate:

Onslaught, previously Survival in Dungeon Defenders, is ♥♥♥♥. Literally. I'm not going to sugar coat it, it's a big steaming pile of ♥♥♥♥. Literally the only reason people run it, is on a super low difficulty, so they can farm gold. Rewards suck. The time it takes to do sucks. Nothing special about it at all. Don't even waste your time, IMO.

Incursion, a slightly different variation from maps, but really nothing different other than throwing mass quantities of mobs at you in each lane. Yeah I guess it's harder but it really doesn't bring anything new to the table. Nothing new, just more mobs, more HP and more damage. Sounds so fun right?

Nightmare 1-4 is my gripe with the game, I suppose. In DD1, we had one nightmare mode and that was it. This game tried to change that and it's pretty much fell flat on its face. There is no difference between Nightmare 1-4 outside of damage numbers. So much engaging gameplay. So you farm the same enemies while you're leveling, to continue farming the same enemies through nightmare 1-4 only scaled higher. Absolutely nothing different, you'll run the same maps until your eyes bleed, and then more.

Pets are bland. Seriously if you played DD1, you're going to be very disappointed here. Liked that mega chicken and it's badass DPS from DD1? Well sorry to say you're going to laugh when you see the pets here.

Overall, this game lacks the fun that Dungeon Defenders 1 had in all aspects. No goofy weapons, no goofy pets, nothing fun at all. Defense speed and range are not a thing here, and I hope you like watching a tower fire slow as hell. Gear is boring in every since of the word, and you'll see what I mean if you play this in comparison to DD1. The same stats, and you'll be looking for 1% upgrades which is laughable to me.

Don't even get me started on the ♥♥♥♥ they've pulled with the latest update they had in which they threw a carnival at us when the game has been needing core changes for months, and what do we get along with it? A 40$ costume that's a reskin. Yes, you read that right. A frickin costume that's 40 bucks. I believe in supporting a game if you enjoy it, but they seriously overstepped their bounds on this. Every patch seems to roll out costume after costume and core gameplay changes that need to be made, have yet to make it into the game.

Take a look at steamcharts and you can see what I mean.


TL;DR: If you enjoy casual relaxed play and just shooting the ♥♥♥♥ with friends and trying out a tower defense game to level to max level and not expect much more than that, check it out.

If you want fun, laughs, and was hoping to see a sequal to the dungeon defenders name, and are expecting a hell of a fun time, avoid it.

My two cents, take it or leave it. Obviously I can't cover every major gripe/perk of the game, and if you want a good view on what players think, check the forums out for yourself and you'll get an idea for how negative they are, especially after last patch.

Obviously I want better changes to come, and I hope they do, I'd really like to recommend this game, but sadly in its current state, I wouldn't recommend it to anyone.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A great sequel to Dungeon Defenders 1
Overview:

The game is very different than DD1 and does not have the same feel to it but still sticks to tower defense of course. It has some features I like a lot that are not in the previous game, and while it is not as good as DD1 at this current time it is still in early access, and can be very much improved. I follow the game and look forward to when it is complete. Still a ways to go but I have enjoyed my experience so far, however there are some things I do miss that were in DD1, that being said the new things in DD2 are a welcomed changed.

Pros:

+4 player co-op
+Auto looting
+Now free to play
+Lovely graphics
+New pet system
+Daily Xp bonuses
+Several game modes
+Great co-op experience
+Cosmetics and costumes
+Daily and monthly challenges
+The squire finally has his pants covered >.<
+Characters are grown up, I wasn't fond of the little toddlers in DD1
+Tower combos, I'd like to see more of this, certain towers do more damage together
+Social tavern is a great addition, allowing many people to converse and group together

Cons:

-No bank to store items
-Community isn't the best
-Still needs tweaking, balancing and fixes
-No lobby list like DD1, makes you join random games
-Game uses too much computer resources, needs optimization
-Cosmetics and costumes seem to be worked on more than everything else
-AFK players, you may come across them, for me it is a big negative, I like active players
-Not enough to do, flow of content is too slow compared to completing it all, leaving nothing to do but daily missions and such.
-Developers are greedy, even after winning money in a lawsuit they continue to put costumes into the game, some of which cost over £20 for a single costume. Optional yes, however the price tags just show you their greed.

Download Size: 7514mb
Trading Cards: 15 cards in the set
Achievement Difficulty: Easy to 100%
Hours to 100%: 100+

Rating: 3/5
Recommendation: Worth playing since it's free

Note: I don't play anymore for now at least, so I won't be updating the review.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you played DD1, you will quickly see that this game is completely gutted. From the leveling to the gear to the social interaction.

Leveling:

-In DD1, leveling always was fun, at any time, you could pick which map you felt you were strong enough for, and you     were rewarded for completing more challenging maps.
-In DD2, it doesn't matter which map you choose, it is much faster to just play the quickest (hard difficulty) map possible, and keep repeating the process. The difficulty is trivial at best, and it just feels like a chore.

Loot:
-In DD1, loot is very diverse when it comes to the stats on the items that are dropped. There is a continuous search on any map for those rare pieces of gear with the perfect stats for your character. Many times, there are pieces with negative stats, because other stats on the gear are over leveled, and it is up the player to decide if the loss in some stats, is worth the gain in others. This makes you want to see how far you can push yourself in each wave to find the most overleveled piece of gear possible, even if it means sacrificing all of your character health and damage, for a full tower stat item.
-In DD2, all loot feels linear. You progress through the maps which have an indicator of what item level of loot will drop. You run the map and get gear that is slightly better than the previous map. You repeat the process, slowly getting better, but never standing out for pushing yourself. You never feel the need to push yourself.

Social Interaction/trading:

-In DD1, you get your own tavern, where you can place items on the floor of your shop, or in your personal shop. In your personal shop, you set prices on any items you wish to sell for mana(currency). Players tend to place the best items on the floor, in an attempt to barter with players that join their shop. It really makes you feel like you are selling something that has meaning, because items can have very unique stats. This makes the player WANT to go do more tougher and tougher maps to improve their shop. Having a personal tavern is one of the best aspects of the whole game, you can spend hours just setting your shop up the way you want it, and chat with customers who enter.
-In DD2, trading is non-existent. You get a personal tavern, but can't sell or trade.

Please Trendy, randomize stats on loot based on map difficulty instead of just increasing the gear by a percentage. Give us taverns that we can sell our items that we work for, and let us level up the way we want to, with more experience based on how tough the map and difficulty is.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Yes yes yes.  The game is great.  Fans of the first game which is also good should enjoy this, and newcomers should as well.  Fans of Dungeon Defenders Eternity, well...we don't talk about that one, but you should enjoy this too.

Currently there are 4 characters.  The monk, the squire, the apprentice, and my personal favorite, the huntress.  Each one has 3 different abilities (with the 4th always being a heal) and 4 different kinds of towers/defenses.  Use these to fend off waves of monsters and bosses who follow paths to try and destroy whatever it is you're defending.  As you play, you will get all kinds of loot drops.  Armor pieces, weapons, and eggs which can be hatched into a bunch of different kinds of pets.  There are quite a few maps, as well as higher difficulties and some different modes to play.  As you level up, you can also unlock special slots that you can place various passive buffs in.

You can play solo, with 3 randoms, or a private lobby with friends.  You'll all be gathered into a cool little player HUB area before you start, where there are all kinds of things you can do.

I do believe however that you need an internet connection to play, so keep that in mind.  If that bothers you, stick with the first game or wait until this one is released and goes F2P.

Lots of fun, definitely worth checking out.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Pre-Alpha[08.12.2014][26 hours]

I played the game for 26 hours now and I can safely say that this game is going in the right direction. It just needs content, changes and some fixes here and there. It runs surprisingly well for a game that’s in pre-alpha. I did glitch through the map once, but I have yet to find another bug.

At the moment it has only 10 maps that all feel unique and rich in detail, and difficulty selection is just like it was in the original. Monster variety is given but there are some monsters that have a higher range than your towers, and since you cant increase your tower range with stats anymore its pretty difficult to counter them. Also there are new monsters immune to physical damange, so squires are not OP anymore, as they were in the original. There are only 4 classes at the moment, with 4 towers and 4 spells each, and the max level cap at 25. Sadly, the game is quite difficult if you play it solo and it even gives you a disadvantage in the rarity of dropped loot. If you play with a group it’s much easier overall, and you get better loot for every additional group member (up to 4), so it seems to be clearly intended for co-op play.

New:

- Combining different elements to get bonus exp/gold is a nice addition to Dungeon Defenders, as it lets you experiment with the different tower elements (water + lightning, knockup + ice, etc).
- There are sub-cores that can now be destroyed without ending the entire round. However, if you let them get destroyed, new enemy paths will open up and you’ll have to build additonal defenses.
- The cores are now unique level based objects that fit nicely with the surrounding map (doors, portals, generators).
- New manually activated traps which do damage in an area, and can only be used again after a cooldown (Gas, Fire, Water).
- Upgrading towers now shows visual changes, which is awesome.
- There are now 2 kinds of mana, which I think is a good thing. (blue for spells and green for towers).
- Items can gain levels by fusing other items into them, which will also reward you with skill points that you can spend on the tower/hero stats on those items.

The graphics seem very minimalistic at first look, but upon closer inspection they are quite detailed close up, a clear and improvement over Dungeon Defenders 1. I personally enjoy the changes, but other fans might be put off. The new tavern looks fantastic and I can't wait to find out what they’ll add in later, as the game is currently in early access.

All in all it’s a solid tower defense game as it is right now and you can have some fun with your friends for sure, but keep in mind that it will be Free to Play on release,  so you might want to wait untill then.

The devs have claimed that the microtransactions will be purely cosmetic (costumes, tower skins, and tavern decorations ), but we’ll see if they can keep that promise. It’s sounds promising but other devs have changed their minds down the road. (Loadout, for example)

There you have it, my first impressions. I will update this review if I encounter anything notable and as I play newer Early Access builds.

Thanks for reading :)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Dungeon Defenders II
Its still pre-alpha, but second version.
I play this game now about 200 hours and i still like it very much. Guess the reason is that the developers always work on this game to improve it. Dungeon Defenders was released in the year 2011. The second part can not be compared to DD. Duneon Defenders II with new 3D animations is the next step with lot`s of improvements. This game belong to the tower defense game genre. The second pre-alpha update include some new game types ( campaign, free play ) like incursion, onslaught, end game, end game incursion and end game onslought. The difficult level has added ( easy, normal, hard ) four new nightmare levels. The match type Quick match is for multiplayer co-op and Private for invited friends only. New pets are available now in epic, mystic and legendary. For all of us who expect more, we can power up and increase our pet`s affection level in order to evolve. It`s necessary to use Shellium shards for evolve. To receive shellium shard let the founded eggs in your inventory about 48 hours. The first pre-alpha offered medium challenge, now with the second alpha it`s more challenge. From easy to hard difficult it`s possible to play single too, but on nightmare it`s obligated to play in a team. The currency in this game are crystals and wyfern tokens. The crystals are included in pre-alpha and the wyfern tokens can be earned in daily and monthly missions. With the crystals for example we can buy more inventory bags, new character slots or discover accessories. For all Uber Speres and lockbox master key it`s possible to pay with wyfern tokens. The balance of this game is good. From the  fondly social and private tavern we can choose challenge on the war table. Bug report is possible too at the tavern keeper. There are some different Shops in this game. The Gran`Masta ( Skill Sphere ) support improvements for hero skills and defense improvements. The Alchemist can improve your items ( clothes, relics and weapons ), simply put all stuff you don`t need inside around your good item and improve your `better choosen item`. The Hatchery for pets can be found at stable boy. For feed your pets go to the Keeper. The Seamstress offers assessories and on the Relic Hunter shop we can buy relics. All special uber skills can be bought on the adventurer token collection shop.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'll keep my review as a no, or a negative review until the problems I have with the game as of the recent patch are dealt with, or fixed in some way.

Anywho, I haven't put as much hours as some people, I do admit but that won't really stop me from knowing enough for a decent review. I think well over 100 hours is perfectly fine for a game such as this one. Overall, I'd say my past 2 days roughly have not been very enjoyed. Honestly, this is a loot based game, and all loot based games generally boil down to the same point. Gear. This games content can run you about 200hrs for the highest difficulty. I had no friends to really play with, and I spent quite a bit of time dicking around. I got there about 125-150hrs if that, the other 50ish was spent again. Messing around, or playing with randoms.

People can tell you that you have to play 1000hrs for a game such as this one, and its clearly not the case. I've played other games, that are more complex and they do not even take that long to understand, or even get to the highest difficulty. That being said, it takes about 100hrs, if you're actually 100% focused on getting to the highest difficulty, and maybe 10-25 depending on your luck to get the gear you need. This includes leveling every character. It just doesn't take that long as people seem to think it does.

This is a pretty sweet game, ESPECIALLY for an ALPHA.. Man, it blew my mind on terms of how well optimized this game is, honestly I think games released sometimes are thrown out in alpha states.. Anyways. on with the Pros.

PROS

- Decent combat

- Lots of variety in ways to play, and extremely customizable builds.

- Well balanced between the characters, none of them really feel Overpowered (trust me, thats a +)

- Nice pet system (actually pretty customizable too)

- A tack to add on to variety in ways to play, You could honestly play strategy or go play it without any strategy in mind.

- Music, its actually really nice. (Although, I think the most recent patch got me looking for positives to this game, and I can't believe I didn't notice how amazing the music was at times)

- The few cutscenes in games were pretty nice, and slightly entertaining

- Developers seem to listen, and quite fast. They seem to take action on it too.

- Visually, this game looks pretty nice. I know some people will beg to differ on that, but I think this game has a nice     style, it doesn't look bad at all. I think it fits the game perfectly.

- Harbinger boss fight is actually quite good, and not as stale as the other one they released. Giant thumbs up for that one.


CONS

- Gear/loot system is terrible now for certain builds, that are unattainable and didn't deserve to get nerfed. Everyone is about average like said in the pros.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I do indeed reccomend this game, especially if you were a fan of DD1. The devs did a good job making this game similar enough to the first one, but added enough originality to call it a brand new game. This is NOT just a retexture of the first one, but so much more, there are now sub cores that if destroyed open a new spawn point for enemies, ability spheres, several levels, and much more. Also, unlike most other early-access games the devs are CONSTANTLY updating, the more you sign in and play the game, the more points you earn to vote on what they add into the game. These people truly care for their players.

Pro's:
- Better looking (Graphics, animations, enemys, tavern)
- Tons more levels, items, and pets.
- New types of equiptable items including vanity items.
- New enemies and boss fights.
- Item leveling requires other items to be enchanted into it, instead of just paying with gems.
- Seperate tower gems and ability gems
- I could freakin' go on forever haha

Con's:
- ONLINE ONLY; This is one thing I don't really like, since a lot of times my internet is down or just bugging out, but there is a private lobby mode, and as long as you have a feint connection to the internet, you should be good.
- The menu is somwhat complicated and progression is unclear, it's hard to tell what missions you have done on what difficulty, and which one you are supposed to do next.

I was a huge fan of DD1 and I am really really exited for the release of DD2 when everything is finished up.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is another of those times that I'm having so much fun with a game, that I feel the need to sit down and share why it is that I feel this way. I first tested DD2 very, very early on, before it was redone to be much closer to its predecessors, Dungeon Defenders, and Dungeon Defenders Eternity. Team Trendy was still deciding on the direction they wanted to go with the project. At the time it was PvP, and I for one am extremely happy that they went back to the tried and true formula that makes the series great. After trying the game again, post-redesign, I bought into the Defense Council, and it's not often that I feel thrilled to have paid $70 for a game. Here are the things this game does SO right:

Dungeon Defenders at its finest:

DD2, even still in alpha, trumps the first 2 games already. The tavern is bigger, better, and packed with things to unlock and discover as you play. The game features quests, NPC's, mad amounts of loot and items, a solid campaign, and once beyond that, multiple new game modes to dive into. For an Early Access title, there is a tremendous amount of content here already, with more updates pouring in every 6 weeks or so. I do look forward to plenty more maps coming in in the future, those are pretty limited currently, but not so much so that you get bored.

Trendy!

Trendy Entertainment, once again, shines in their interactions with the community, in addressing bugs and issues, and in building a great experience. These guys GET IT. I mean REALLY get it, when it comes to how to treat the community, and even in alpha they're right on top of things. You'll see them reply to nearly every thread, and for a game with around 14,000 concurrent users at the time of writing this, that's impressive to say the least. They've gone above and beyond the call, even compensating the community when issues arise which reset quests or cause the players to lose progress. This is an alpha, we will ALL lose progress at times, but these guys still know how frustrating that can be!

Immersion

One of the big surprises for me in DD2 was getting into the campaign and seeing more than just the same crystals to defend. There are interactive traps on the map, and other things to defend besides just the main crystal. In one case, there were even NPC's on the map, cowering up near the throne while you defended them and kept them alive. Tel ya what, having actual characters there made it feel so much more worthwhile! Who wants to defend an empty throne? I love the added depth they've brought to DD2, it brings so much life to the game!

F2P done RIGHT!

Trendy has done a perfect job with the cash shop. There is absolutely nothing pay to win in DD2, and never will be. It's a promise they made, and have stuck to like glue. You can buy costumes, bags, things like that, but never boosts, or anything that changes the way the game is played. You can't go to the cash shop and make your game any easier, or make it impact the experience. You can sure look great though! The costumes for each character are quite cool, and worth a spend for people looking to support the development of the game.

Additionally, even with an already bustling community, I LOVE the option for private taverns/friends only gameplay. Let's face it, most people don't want to play with that guy"

There's still alot of things wrong with the game.
One frustrating bug i encountered was said to have been around for over a year with nothing done to adress it.
But these are bugs and even if Trendy works slowly, they will be resolved and i am ALOT more confident in saying today, that i am happy with what Trendy has done with DD2 over the last year. Alot of strong updates to the game and i'm looking forward to seeing the full package.

Not recommending because its still in alpha/beta (whatever its called these day) and bugs are a frequent thing. If you love the game you should wait untill its full release, when bugs wont frustrate you into abandoning the game.

Really liking the game so far.
Got roughly 100 hours in this game of which most was in the first two weeks.
That kinda goes to show that even though the game is a lot of fun in it's current state it is also still lacking.

upsides :
- the game feels super smooth, other than two crashes I had on day 1 I've had no bad experiences at all concerning the smoothness.
- nice map variation, sure there are not an insane amount of maps yet but the ones we have are pretty diverse.
- Abilities of classes are a lot more fun to use compared to DunDef1, squire for example has a taunt and an AoE stun that are just a total joy to use.
- friend system works nicely and due to the way downscaling works you can always play with your friends even if they are low level. ( though obviously a full geared level 25 that is downscaled will still be a bit stronger than a normal level 1 ).

Downsides:
- Only 4 classes, this is mainly due to the game being in early access so I will remove this one eventually but for now it feels lacking even though they are working hard on it.
- Some towers are completely useless while others are a must.  This is also a temporary thing with balance patches coming in the future but I had to throw it down since at the current state some towers are just vastly superior to others.

There might have been some things that I missed out on but all in all I greatly enjoyed playing the game and will check back with every big patch , on that note a big patch is coming again soon so those kinda waiting with buying it should totally get it when the patch comes out.

edit:  removed the lack of endless survival mode from downsides since it was recently added.
This game is being updated a lot and I still have high hopes for the future.

LOVE THIS GAME!!!

(I never played Dungeon Defenders 1 before anyone asks)

So I got this game today and I played it for 8hours straight and literally could not stop playing it.
As I write this review, it is 2AM in the morning for me because I am so addicted to the game!

I enjoy this game so much I sent my wife a key and she is also now addicted to the game, we cannot stop playing it.

So let's get into the game itself!

Graphics: So the graphics are basically a cartoon easy free mesh style with nothing amazing or special to look at, but it does offer some nice aspect to play with a cartoon/ anime feel which draws you into the game with the cool design, meaning the game feels different and runs smooth because of the unique design! Overal decent to look at for once, very colourful!

Audio: The audio is actually suprisingly good, cute cat meows, funny slashing with monsters growing, cool weapon swooshing and bangs with some really really relaxing old style music that draws you in!

Gameplay: The gameplay is pretty simple! Seriosuly the character controls and the way you move is so smooth and easy, you master the game in seconds and cannot complain!
It is basically a tower defense with a mixed in RPG (XP, stats, money, armour etc) so you earn coins and ranks, with armour offering certain things to make you better, you get pets which are awesome from eggs to hatch into some more support... It feels like Fable meets Diablo too me which is pretty decent to me (Even though I do not like Diablo) but this game really you work at it, play with friends, form defences and fight to survive against monsters.
It also feels a lot like Orcs Must Die" which is another amazing game but this game feels more refined and balanced correctly!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Dungeon Defenders 2 Review
TL;DR -  Video Review

The kids have grown up!  In Dungeon Defenders 2 you continue the story as the apprentice, the squire, the huntress, or the monk.  The kids are now what appear to be teenagers with slick overhauled graphics.  And, More characters are coming.  The game is now in early access on Steam and I thought I would provide my initial impressions on this unique game.

Just like the original dungeon defenders game, this is also a hybrid tower defense and Action RPG.  You still get all the same fun loot collecting, leveling, and skill points, along with a slightly tweaked gear upgrade system.

Before I get too far down the rabbit hole, I was an original Dungeon Defenders 2 Defense Council Member.  This meant I have seen every build prior to the Steam Early Access public release.  This game has progressed immensely from the days of its infancy and with much excitement I am glad to say this is one of the best feeling Early Access" games I have experienced in a long time.  They did right by the community and didn't release a buggy product.  I have yet to see a crash.  The only issues I have noticed are a few camera clipping issues.

From the first few moments in the game you can tell this is a smooth product.  If you were a player of the original this will feel liquid
date: with a slightly faster pacing.  When the game was initially announced it was going to be a MOBA styled tower defense game that was free to play.  A lot of the original fans were obviously upset that it wasn’t a true continuation of the original game; I was not one of them.  I thought the MOBA style might provide something unique to this game but those ideas were tabled
recommended: but will it probably make an appearance in the future in some form.\n\nThe game did keep the Free to Play ideology though and that will likely propel this game to new heights on the PC.  However to actually in the "Early Access" you do have to purchase a copy for $25
hoursPlayed: or catch it on sale.  This does come with perks such as premium currency

votesTotal:
I quote "Never grant gameplay advantage. Ever."

Being part of Early Access does have a unique perk. Influence.  Influence points are earned every day you login which can be spent to vote on what various features or implementations of features in coming builds.

Back to the game

commentsCount: along with ability to upgrade the existing towers.  Another area where this game excels over its predecessor is the new Wave Director which will slightly randomize enemy waves.  This could mean different enemy types

reviewText:
Early Access Review

In short, not yet, maybe never.

It's still early access, but after playing about 35 hours, I'm probably not coming back.  They tried to stagger your abilities, you get something new practically every round, but it's still about playing the same maps over and over.  I was level 30+, but I couldn't even play the events.  Pretty lame.

I don't even know why they have the tavern.  It's just a glorified menu.  There's no interaction with anyone in there, and when you're in a shared tavern you are likely to get sucked into a game on accident.  That will drop you out of whatever thing you were doing.

Balance is a big issue.  Having a ranged weapon that fires two projectiles is dumb, because neither of them go straight.  They also do 1/2 damage each, so you might as well just get a 1 projectile weapon and hit things.  Attack speed is the same, you do the same DPS whether you're firing 1 or 4 projectiles per second.  There are a few interesting weapons, but they become obsolete very quickly.  Higher tier items have a formula.  You get more effects, but the stats are the same.  The effects are totally unbalanced.  Some of them are super powerful while others don't even make sense.  Eventually I just sold all weapons if they didn't drain HP or if they fired multiple projectiles.

For a game that is all about items, item management is stupid.  You can get hundreds of drops per round, but there's no way to just sell all the low quality ones or anything.  No favorites.  No filtering.  Just a pain.  I was spending more time selling items than I was playing the game, what with all the waiting for rounds to start and an item overflow that times out too quickly.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Waited some time for a few patches before I decided to review.  Has it been 2 years already?

Well like most I was highly anticipating this game and was expecting that original DD feeling.  Did I get that?  ...Not exactly, but that is ok given games have to evolve in some way, even though it's not always based on our personal wants & needs.  At first I was excited and then somewhat disappointed and then hardly play anymore, but I come back time to time and it seems DDII can't grab me and keep me prisoner like the original still can.  I still recommend this because it has some changes coming, but replay-wise for now, not so much.  I still love the DD universe and appreciate all its parts, so hoping that flare to keep playing returns.

NOTE:  Some of the below are based on friends of friends opinions, but seem to be matching equally to random people I asked the same question.

PROS:

1. Familiar Music themes
2. Familiar map areas revamped
3. A little more hero customizations
4. Knight actually welds a shield without being an accessory
5. Graphics are well done frame to frame animations
6. Still maintains that unique hero feeling
7. Abilities are a bit different, but still enjoyable
8. Handling pets has changed
9. New Quest system is realistic & fun
10. Month-to-month quests for pets & other rewards is a nice addition
11. Still has that Boss Fight fun factor
12. Customizing inventory = Names, auto-loot categories, by class, etc and etc
13. Easy leveling

CONS:

1. Limited inventory compared to the original
2. You have to purchase inventory slots (Bags)
3. Towers to damage to creature formulas have changed
4. Huge limitations on gear upgrades compared to original DD
5. Handling pets has changed (placed as PRO and CON because it’s a huge argument to most in my circles and circles of circles)
6. Open tavern creates some negative feedback on the community as a whole and reporting system might as well not exist (can be avoided with solo tavern play or private + inviting friends); which leads to a very immature atmosphere
7.  Normal Mode difficulty does not feel like Normal mode, so difficulty to difficulty is not a realistic transition from one to the other.


Most arguable PROS & CONS:

Handling pets
Graphics
Abilities
Open Tavern with no control or monitoring
Difficulty
Easy leveling (easy to vets but to new players? ...compared to the original)


All-in-all I love that the DD community is still going in some way, but... (PERSONAL OPINIONS SECTION)

1. Did it grab me and dedicate me like the original?       No
2. Do I feel Trendy was able to make a worthy sequel?    Yes, but wanted that old rewarding feeling
3. Am I already finding myself anticipating the next Dungeon Defenders?    Yes
4. Will I still play DDII?    Yes, but not daily = a couple times a month
5. Am I not playing due to the unregulated chat?    No, but I see how the racist names and 24/7 bashing among people in the community can alienate many new players and some vets alike.
6. Will I stream DDII?    No, and it's not because the community is very small, it's just that I only stream/record games I play daily to almost daily = no streaming or YouTube

So basically I like this game and can recommend it, because I do play it, but for me it lacks that replay value like the original granted.


Sirspoony rating:    7.5/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a game with a bit of graphics and well.. did i mention it have stuff that moves on your computer screen?
The rest is a bit lacking...

Not that fun not that rewarding, It's like that friend you have that always promises that he will change but still makes the same stupid mistakes over and over. He tells you that he values your input and listens to what you say. But then ignores you and runs away yelling lololololol while wearing a crazy cap (CC for short).

All you can do is stare at the thing that moves, like your hypnotized by the movement and the stupity. You know you could do something better with your time. Do it, run away from the guy with the CC. It's not worth it, he will never change. It's all empty promises.

There comes a point in every gamers life, when you must realize what's in front of you and let go... Just let it go.. Or don't go there in the first place. It's a wery bad and dark place filled of regrets, and restless nights waking up screaming in the middle of the night...

Remeber It's all a fantasy, like the fantasy you have about this game ever being any good. It's time to face reality.



And if you who tried DD1, DD2 is not the new DD, it's something else but with the same name. The game is just not that interesting or fun. It's like a dull idle game / hold down the button action rpg hybrid.

I have som great memories from DD1, played it around 300 hours. Lots of maps that was fun to explore, just running the map and failing a lot of time just to understand the mob movement, was part of the fun. Finding unique loot on the maps, and big maps that you could get lost running around. There was always a sense of progress. A lot of...  let's try that map again and see if i can go one wave furter, maybe if i tweak a little here and a little there. There was a lot more strategy involved in DD1.

DD2 is like a no brainer action-rpg with towers. You get a clear line that shows where the mobs will be, and chokepoints pointed out where you should build your defences. A lot more focus around finding the right loot, not upgrading loot as in DD1. Now you can spend days just farming for the perfect loot so you can take on the same map as you where farming the loot on.

Even the skins in DD1 was a lot more rewarding since you hade to accomplish something to get the skins, now you just hand over your money and get your skin.

Most of the time you fail a map while in a group is because someone from your team fell asleep and forgot to repair the wall. Or was watching youtube on his/her laptop while holding down the fire butting pointing the bow down a lane not caring what happens in the game at all.

This game is so bad i regret playing it, I could have done so mutch more with my time like staring at paint while it's drying or contemplating my navel.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So i thought after all this time i should step up and bring you guys my review:

Early Access review: As an early access game you can only notice 2 things:
- Small balance issues (which are being worked on daily)
- Content (specially end game and higher difficulty)
These are not game breaking of any kind, it's the less buggish early access i've played (Did i mention that it's still only pre alpha? Man the game totally feels way better).

So should you get this game?
Well that depends, the game will be F2p, if you have your doubts and only want to test you might wanna wait, now the game is early access, so that means there might be wipes and lack of appropriate content for the time you want to spend in the game, but you can always entertain yourself in many other ways and help the game develop. If you're okay with purchasing a game that's not released yet don't doubt it. If you want to help the game get better, go ahead and don't think twice.

FAQ:
-Do Developers even care about the feedback? Definitely they do! Many changes have been made for community request, and many were added. There's even an influence system that you can vote with points you gain by being active!
-Dev Interaction? Yes there are streams every thursday and friday ; Forum activity by the Devs ; A devlog coming out weekly about what the devs are working on!
-Better than DD1? Dungeon Defenders 1 is a full complete game, i believe DD2 has potential to be way way better than DD1, but it's still Pre-Alpha, so it's normal you might not find as interesting.
-F2P? Won't that be P2W? Nope the game will have no such a thing as sold advantage, it will depend on costumes and all type of cosmetics and whatelse they can come up with but no sold advantage of any sort =).

There's a lot of info i want to give you about the game to help you judge it, but go ahead and watch the streams/videos and decide for yourself, i found myself getting the game a while ago, and i simply love it, love the game love the dev interaction, totally worth it, this game is going to rock for me. There are some changes that must be made but i believe all that will come in time!

The game is very similar to the first one in some points, even the graphics that everyone likes, even if I like the first one better, a matter of personal taste, I recognize the improvements.

On the similar aspects, I give a thumbs up. As the first one the gameplay is very cool and the maps are wonderful. The characters and towers are very much alike too.

The bad parts are the one that differs from the original DD. As you level up you are given a very limited and poor choices of specs for your skills and, as I have seen, most of the choices are pretty useless. That messes up a bit with your character customization, since you are forec to buff up a single tower with your specs, and once you get 10+ points on that skill its upgrading becomes pretty useless, since you wil get a 0.45% boost on that skill or less.

The other aspect is that you can't level up the things you want to play with. You can't level up tower damage, health, hero speed, attack speed etc. You depend on item drop to do that, and you depend A LOT on item drop (and I say A LOT). You can go almost 30 hero levels without ever finding a gear that fits your hero, so you won't play it the way you want for a very long time. That is a terrible decision by the game designers and, for me, what ruined the game, because what makes a good RPG is character creation and the fact that you can costumize you hero to play the way you want to play it. DD2 won't let you.

Personaly I like to play builder. That is not an option either in DD2, since you get enough build mana" to build one or maybe two towers in a map. And

Game is far too different from the first one so far, in a bad way.

- Each hero now only has 4 towers (used to be 5)
- Unique towers have been removed (electric tower, ensnare aura, bouncer blockade, etc)
- Monk has lost all but one of his auras
- Many of these new gear passives enforce 'meta' builds
- Melee combat is uncomfortable with the new 'lunge forward with every attack' thing
- Resistances have been condensed into two categories (DD1 had 4)
- Enemies are less interesting
- Imo, the graphics feel unfinished, worse than DD1 even

There have been improvements, but for them to come at the cost some of the core features many of us loved about the first game isn't worth it. The game is just too different. Had Trendy not changed all of these things so drastically and seemingly without good reason, and just improved the stuff that needed it, this game could have been a smash. As it stands, I'm not a fan of this game and wouldn't recommend it.

DD1 was amazing

Bought this before Steam early access and was VERY disapointed.
The original pitch for DD2 is that it was going to be a MOBA game and I had ZERO interest in buying it, Then they announced they had scrapped that idea went back to the drawing board and were going to stay more true to the original - They did not.

If you prefer the tower defence side to the combat side (as I do) I just cannot recommend this game, Which is unfortunate as DD1 was such a masterpiece.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

What happened to Dungeon Defenders 2?

In short: I no longer like the look and feel the game has. I just don’t enjoy playing these “walking stick” characters. I feel that all the small things, that made me enjoy DD1, are no longer part of DD2.
For me personally, it’s a huge step back from DD1.

The first thing I noticed when I played is, that nothing is familiar. Everything is completely different and not in a good way. All the menus such as character, level and inventory menus are very confusing. The enjoyment of upgrading your character and spending time on searching through good items, is no longer there for me. I find find it rather annoying and confusing to go through all the menus.

In DD1, the mana crystals which are needed to build towers, were so much fun to collect. In DD2, I don’t even see them properly. What happened? Why are they so tiny?

Same for all monsters and player characters along with the weapons. They’re all so small and look like walking sticks. Sometimes the monsters blend into the environment and you can’t even make them out. I don’t like the art design of the 3D models that they went with. I prefer the more “bubbly” look from DD1.

Towers? I loved playing a mage in DD1, the art design was great, but in DD2 all the mage towers look cheap, as if they were rushed.

And no, don’t say “Oh but early access, they might change these things”. No they don’t. The development of the game is now focusing on optimizing the game and bug fixes, they are not making any major changes anymore.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

NOTE: Keep in mind, the game must be paid for in order to play at the moment, as it is in Early Access. It will become Free To Play at around the end of the year. Also, a lot of the negative reviews on the front page are complaining about issues that have been fixed or changed or complaining about features that are not in the game YET.

In my opinion, This game has a lot of potential. Even though it is currently in early access, it feels like it has enough replayibility to keep me going for hundreds of hours with the latest update. Now, here are some of the pros and cons for the game in its current state.

Some Pros:

+ Pretty art design, the way it is done gives the game a more 'Toon' feel to it.
+ Alot more enemy diversity compared to DD1.
+ The Game is regularly updated, with the latest patch adding loads of content in to the game.
+ The people who work on the game interact with the community and hold Developer streams on Twitch every friday.
+ According to the developers, There won't be DLC Map packs, so the community won't be split.
+ The music in the game is good.
+ The towers have more 'Personality' as i would call it...
+ Once it goes F2P, It won't be P2W.
+ Betsy and cute Propellor Cats
+ If you do buy Early Access, you get $30 worth of ingame currency to buy costumes with.

A few Cons:

- It's in early access, so you have to pay to be able to play it.
- Tavern is laggy and the game feels slightly unoptimized.
- Uber Skill Spheres cost waaaaaaay too many Wyvern Tokens.. (i call the tokens 'Betsy Bucks')
- Level cap that does not take long to reach. (Level Cap will be increased later on)
- Earlier maps become meaningless to play once you hit level 25. (They are adding Incursions soon for them to make them playable in late game again)
- Bug paradise
- No controller support yet.

Note: Most of the problems i have with the game a due to the game still being in development and a lot of the features are not in it yet.

Final Verdict:

While the game is unfinished and has it's fair share of problems, it's fun, which is what people really look for in games.

8/10 (in it's current state)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I am having trouble enjoying this game anymore, even though I want to.

Pros:
You can get fun outfits without having to pay real money for them.
You can get some of the highest lvl pets without having to pay real money for them.
There is no pay to win aspect in this game.

With those pros you would think that this game would be a great mmo tower defense, but the cons make you loath the process you have to undergo in order to even attempt the nightmare difficulty playthroughs. DD2 stops being a game of strategy long before you reach even the hard or insane difficulty levels preceding the nightmare ones.

Cons:
Grind, Grind, Grind goes the player. Item drops are arbitrary. What I mean by this is that the high lvl gear that drops as you solo a difficult map, will hardly ever be gear you actually want for ANY of your characters.

What adds insult to injury is the carnival ticket mechanic. During every map playthrough, carnival ticket's drop, and for every 10 tickets that drop, you can spin the carnival wheel for the chance of getting Legendary gear of your current avg item lvl. This is the only way to dependably get good gear, because Legendary gear is the best in the game. So, even if it is not perfect for your build you may still be able to use it. To use the wheel in this way requires that you equip terrible tier gear that have high item lvls. This way you increase your avg item level before you spin the wheel.

If you do not have tickets, you can use 2500 in game currency to spin the wheel. So, you end up farming maps for gold, then spinning the wheel until you get better gear, finally playing the same old maps at a higher difficulty setting, and then restarting the process all over again to advance to the next difficulty setting.

Therefore, this game is more than just a grind fest, but also a redundant waste of time with no true reward for effort expended.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Charming. Technically tower defense but not really. Hack-n-slash and pew pew game that takes almost no skill at all. Farm endlessly for no reason because there's literally nothing else to do.

No real strategy. Basically block off every path and prevent the mobs from getting through. Have good gear = win. Not having good gear actually makes it fun and challenging but the fun doesn't last all that long.

There's essentially one only one way to play each of the 4 characters. There is no depth to this game at all.

High level play, like level 30+, devolves to players swapping their high level characters in to place OP towers and afk every round. Bugged flying mobs are the only thing keeping people active because it slows down the farmfest. Beyond level 40 the game begins to feel nearly dead. Probably because people with half a brain don't keep playing hoping it gets more interesting like I did. There are barely any players to play with aside from the farmers. Once you find a farmer, you can afk and go do something better with your time. Literally anything.

You constantly replace gear because this game is all about ascending and descending in power. Take a few zeros off the numbers and check it out! It's as if you're still level 10! The difference is maybe your weapon looks cooler and your gear icons glow and have colorful borders.

The gear you are constantly replacing isn't shown on your character. Instead, the devs have opted for costumes that you can buy with real money so your character actually changes appearance aside from weapons. Some of the costumes are cool but that's not going to excuse how silly the Squire runs and pretty much just makes it look even more ridiculous. It's like the devs looked at the melee character and said, Make this one pretty much ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥." However
date: the attack animations are pretty damned good. The character goes from derp to Spartan warrior at the click of a button.\n\nIt's charming and could be cool but deep down
recommended: just like The Mighty Quest for Epic Loot
hoursPlayed: it's garbage and will be until time erases it."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Firstly, the game is good but a few things have just irked me from the get go. The fact that when you level you cant put any upgrade points into tower stats is a massive fail, it is necessary to reinstate this to be able to even have the smallest chance on higher difficulties. The fact is to improve your towers you are completelly reliant on equpment drops (which are rare as ♥♥♥♥)
The lack of controller support is annoying for now but i understand that this will be added later so isnt that important of a point to make now.
The graphics are a nice improvement and i like the art style in general.
Trash equpment that nobody wishes to pick up now no longer vanishes and gets banked at the end of each wave it stays until the end of the map making everything look cluttered by the end and instead of auto selling everything and splitting the cash it splits it into each persons inventory which you then have to manually sell or wait a few days for the auto sell.
the preorder stated $30 of in game cash but my account has 0, not sure if thats a UK thing but i havent got a dime.

The map order is strange and have yet had a chance to work out what sort of order I should be doing them in with no solid structure like numbering added to the map names it is slightly confusing. The lobbies need an option to kick or to votekick idle players as they come in the game and build a few towers the reap the benefits of xp with no action able to be taken against them and it gets worse when the random lobby host is rolled onto them on endgame and everyone has to find a new lobby.

The building mana needs to have a higher drop rate as I have gone through games only being able to build a handful of towers that are then just destroyed as I dont have enough mana to upgrade or repair them.

To sum up, levelling feels pointless apart from being able to equip slightly better armour now and then when the lynchpin of all rpg style games is character progression and on dd2 it feels completely dead and worthless. Many more issues such as droprates need to be looked at and until this is updated i will probably stay away from this game for now. I will change my reccomendation upon further updates if improvements are made.

Ive tried to like this game but just cant. It just feels like a generic knockoff of Dungeon Defenders 1. The levels feel really claustrophobic, the lanes are so tight that when your towers are firing down a lane it looks like the finale to a 4th of july fireworks show, obscuring all sight of what is actually coming down the lane. The movement just doesnt feel intuitive and many objects on the levels seem to have almost the same height as your jumps apex making navigation through the tight levels a pain. The only thing i do like is the new action skills but other then that the game is a huge letdown and id recommend just playing DD1 over this mess.

**Update: The game has improved alot. theyve fixed some of the movement issues. collisions could use some work because atm u get stuck on many invisible objects and cant walk over any little bump so u have to jump alot to get onto things that you would think u could just walk right up onto. its easier to see the mobs coming over the graphical effects from your towers, although it can still get a little crazy at times and could be toned down abit or use more transparent effects. atm they seem to use alot of opaque 2d sprites for effects that obscure everything behind them. net code could use work when your in the tavern but seems to be pretty good in co-op matches. figuring what stats have what on an item has been greatly simplified and is much more intuitive now. im still not a fan of the small inventory. u can buy larger bags with earned gold though so thats a plus and alleviates quite abit of that headache but it still feels lacking when u start to play multiple char's. overall though they have improved the game greatly and is worth trying if u were a big DD1 fan. keep an eye on it atleast.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Warning beforehand: I am going to use this to say what I want the game to be like. It may not be your viewpoint, so proceed with caution.

UPDATE 3
After coming to check this out again after the Halloween patch, I was pleased to find levelups give you more control over your character, two new maps, and other additions such as weapon types. For the first time since I bought it, I felt that the Dungeon Defenders experience was becoming cohesive. If they continue along this path I feel we're sure to get something worth a look. It may not measure up to DD1's legacy just yet, but I'm hopeful that we're going to see something great. I still have problems with Item Power and I wish item descriptions were given like the original game (those icons made it easy to know exactly what your weapon was gonna give you at a glance. Text doesn't work as well for me.) but it's gotten better since the last update. Also, it's free, so anyone can give it a go and make a more informed decision. Seriously, stop reading reviews and go give it a go.

UPDATE 2
With the Loot and Survive patch, the game has come much closer to being something I'd spend a lot of time on. With the addition of a real campaign and direction, the maps are tied together much more compellingly. However, beyond the campaign has been problematic, though they have and will continue to fix issues. I do take issue with the Item Power system, as it is consistently inaccurate with its representation of items, forcing me to appraise items myself (for instance, an item that would give me around 50 of both magical and physical resistance was placed below one with 50 physical resistance). This is frustrating. In addition, I still wish for more customization (levelups are meaningless to me without my input on how my character grows). That aside, however, for the most part this was a good update.

UPDATE
Having played the new patch, I've noticed a few things. One: They have begun monetization and Costumes are now available for purchase with gems. In addition, the Perks system has been replaced by a new system I haven't had time to try out, but seems sound in theory. However, it's a mixed bag: I've noticed an abundance of Chests, which can be opened for rare items and costumes...with Gems. That feels very P2W to me, and I'm very against it. That's really the only black mark on DD2's record at the moment, but it's a big one. EDIT: The Skill Spheres system is much closer to customization than the previous system, with the highest-level sphere completely changing your one of your towers. While I would love for them to go even farther, I'm happy with Spheres.
EDIT: Fixed a typo (spear).

First off, Dungeon Defenders II is a very pretty game. It looks excellent, the gameplay feels solid, but it's missing one core element that made me spend hundreds of hours in Dungeon Defenders 1: Customization. Perks are nice, but they don't change gameplay. The beauty of DunDef1 was in the myriad of playstyles: I built a ferocious multishot apprentice that would zip around the map, mowing enemies down. He couldn't build towers AT ALL, but he was strong. I had another Apprentice that couldn't fight at all, but had unrivaled towers. These both made the game VERY different to play through, and that was awesome.

I'm not getting that in Dungeon Defenders II.

That said, it's still very enjoyable. I just don't see myself investing hundreds of hours, I see myself investing a few more every time they update. And I don't want it to be like that.

Should you buy? If you liked Dungeon Defenders 1, then sure. If not, give that one a go and come back.
