reviewText:
Early Access Review

*GASP*! A new hero! Stuck behind a grindy pay-wall.......... I supported this game forever ago with a lot of cash and I have to grind or pay $10 USD for the new content. I love DLC in early access games <3. Before you charge me for new content, polish your netcode and engine.

I still stand behind the idea that you'll get your time's worth of entertainment here. That being said, after leveling one or two characters, there isn't any reason to return to the game. It's not the lack of content, but the lack of well-polished content. Loot is confusing and clunkier than it was before, and there quickly becomes no incentive to play early-encountered maps. You'll still enjoy your time here, even if that time is less than 20 hours.

--- ORIGINAL REVIEW ---

TLDR: Great MMO-Tower Defense-RPG romp with enough content on offer to justify the purchase as-is.

An incredible experience. Well worth the fee to enter the Alpha. I'd be freaking enraged if the developers did not make true on their word and finish the game with the features they had discussed. But, I wouldn't feel like I was out any money if they didn't. I've had so much fun with the content on offer, and there is a ton of it. About 10 hours to beat the campaign with each character (for a total of 40), and you will not be max level by then.

After that, there are still about 4 more gameplay modes that your characters can enjoy that help level them to the cap! In addition, the Free-To-Play model being implemented here is solely for skin customizations and inventory space. (Spend your gems on the inventory space) Skins can be unlocked through random crate drops a la Counter-Strike, but those can be opened with tokens earned in-game. These Wyvern Tokens aren't too grindy to earn.

All-in-all I've had a ton of fun with it! I'm working on a playthrough right now. Give it a watch if you want to see what it's all about! - https://youtu.be/EBuZi24W4f8

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Decent game, did not live up to DD1
Admittedly, this game is fun. The item progression and character progression make you feel more powerful as you play. The art style is unique and fun. Having it free to play is a bold move, but having paid for access earlier, I do not feel rewarded.

However, this is a shell of what it could have been. Dungeon Defenders 1 had more classes, a better item system, a higher level cap and even more enemies (feels better killing 1000 enemies rather than 100). Rather than refining on a tried and true model, they created a different game, taking multiple steps backwards. Character leveling takes far too long, enemies do not spawn properly, waves take ages...

After the trainwreck of Dungeon Defenders Eternity and this game falling flat, I cannot recommend this game, or even Trendy. While they produce many podcasts, they seem to have almost no involvement with the community (or at least the vast majority). The games have tons of bugs, many of which should have been easy fixes. It's laughable, really.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Well, where should I begin?

Dungeon defenders 2 is the sequel to what's probably one of my favourite games, to be honest, it's quite disappointing but I can't hold too much against it as it is only in alpha at the moment, if I haven't updated this and it's in like beta when you're reading this then you should probably just ignore it. This is what I will say for now, however:
The game is rather similar to the original DD but to me it just feels straight up bad in comparison. Let's talk about the main two components of both games, combat and strategy:

The combat of this game is quite different to the original, in the original you will be greeted by hordes of weak enemies who surround you and make combat a challenge as you smoothly slice or gun them down dodging lots of orcs (basically like big tank enemies who slowly swing big axes) and projectiles along the way, it sounds easy but as there are so many of them, it makes it an awesome but still balanced challenge.
However, in this second installment, it's changed for the worse, there are around 15 enemies on each part who all just feel a chore to kill, they have a lot more health but as it's not a proper fun horde, they are all easy to dodge and kill, it just takes AGES, it takes around 5 hits just to kill a goblin (a small enemy which is extremely weak, obviously there are a lot more in DD1). Did I mention melee? Using a melee weapon is just annoying as anything, every attack lunges you forward in the most awkward and uncontrollable way with a melee weapon. I've fell off cliffs trying to fight as a squire (the knight class in the game), so melee weapons and melee combat has just turned to total crap. Ranged weapons aren't any better though, really, all you do with one is move backward and shoot, which is no fun, I'd probably rather be a messed up knight, jerking uncontrollably. Basically, all the combat really is, is hitting and using your abilites when you can (just extra powerful attacks in this game really, and self healing). Squires can block but in this game it's useless as anything, I don't even see any difference in the damage they do me.

The strategy in this is probably even worse than the combat, let's start with DD1, all the maps could be built up in lots of different ways, some ways a lot better than others, all of the good looking builds worth trying, if you're smart (or you just have ridiculously high stats for the level) you can just build up and sit back to watch it perfectly working, or just grab a cup of tea. Now let's look at DD2, there are two obvious builds for every map, put turrets on the walls of the map and walls to block them off as they die, or just put turrets and walls on the obvious bits of the path. Both aren't really that different at all and no matter whether you chose the best out of the two possible decent builds or not, all the towers need constant supervision, repairing, fighting and all that. There are also environmental traps (such as valves you turn to release smoke and damage the enemies) which you NEED to use, forcing a lot of players in one game, it's hard to play with just one friend, you end up on a public game packed with 7 year old idiots. All the towers also have huge like spaceboxes so you can't place a tower within a meter's range of another, making placing them properly difficult, in DD1 they just couldn't overlap, unless they were monk or hunter traps. In short, there's no real strategy, you just need to run around like a headless chicken attending to your towers and activating environmental traps.

Let's move on to looting, this isn't that main a thing in both but it gets a verrrrrrrrrrrry annoying in DD2, you get a new, better weapon almost every wave and upgrading them does barely anything to the stats, all considered (In DD1 you need to upgrade your weapon to do good damage, which in my opinion is good). There is an option to automatically collect loot but it fills up the few bag spaces you have in DD2 very fast and you find yourself sorting good from rubbish after every level. There aren't many different models the items can spawn with either, so you will probably find someone with the same weapon as you in a public tavern. There's also only like 20 different pets in DD2 but tonnes in DD1 and in DD1 EVERYTHING spawns in different sizes and colours, nothing does in 2. This makes looting very bland. The items do spawn with different weights but this is broken so that heavier weapons do more damage per second, even with the same damage stats.

Now on to DLC, there's a lot of better, more optional and reasonably priced DLC in the first game, such as different characters with unique abilities but in DD2 it's inventory space for £20, More items and IN GAME FREAKING CURRENCY(!!!!!!!!!!!!??????????) for £30, how reasonably priced, fun and worth it this is (sarcasm BTW), oh and if anyone wants it's £17 for a costume pack on special offer!

Summary:
DD2= rubbish
DD1= awesome
If you like the look of this then just play DD1, you'll have a much better time.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

For an early access game, it's largely in great shape compared to other games that are either completely unfufilled games or broken.  The fact that it's F2P is even more amazing.

Absolutely nothing about the game is P2W.  Almost everything purchased with cash is cosmetic.

Lots of potential for people who came from DD1, and with continued support from Trendy will be a huge success.

The game isn't without it's issues or quirks.  Thankfully the support staff either here, the discussion boards or the official forums are all quick to help. A lot of the issues I've seen or have known others to encounter are largely quality of life issues and don't cause the game to be completely unplayable.

Considering the cost to buy the game, there isn't much of a reason why anyone shouldn't download it and give it a try.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So after 38 hours of gametime and three lv.25 characters i think it's finally time for a review to give you my opinions about the game in it's pre-alpha stage.

So to begin with i'm gonna say that i really loved DD1 but it feels like i won't give DD2 a chance if i would compare the two to eachother, especially when DD2 is just in it's alpha stage. So i just left DD1 behind and seeked out all the great potential from DD2 (Comparing DD1 to DD2 will be more fair when DD2 gets an actual release)

-So the game can be played both solo and with other players, i've been playing solo more or less all the way and i haven't encountered any problems that way (My experience when playing with others was just frustrating, lack of communication and semi-afk people)

But i would say that the game feels very smooth with it's wonderful design, a very toony feel which i absolutely love within games. It sorta feels like it's a key enhancer for this game.

I've encountered some small freeze lags here and there (especially when i upgrade items), but it's really no big of a deal. I wouldn't expect anything else from a pre-alpha game.

The way you choose maps in the game so far so is to me a big mystery.. I don't think anyone would say it's a very appealing to replay old levels at a little harder difficulty.. It becomes boring

Throw some ideas at trendy how to make ^above^ better.

But let's just cut to the end,

Do i recommend this game?: Of course i do! It's a fun addictive game that you can enjoy for many hours to come. And i have a big trust in Trendy :)

I wanna throw in some words from another review i read before: If Trendy follows their heart it's bound to become good, Very much true!

Early Access Review

Bought this game and now it's free.

I don't care if I received in-game currency for my purchase, that was supposed to be a bonus with the purchase, not a hidden purchase as it now seems it was.

As far as gameplay goes, I loved this game for a while, but it becomes a gear grind if you want to play into the really high tier nightmare modes. Then finding a game with anyone else is impossible so you have to grind every class to be able to solo, or just play Squire because they're the only class that really needs no other class's help to solo.  Every other class can not solo end game well enough without the best of the best gear, and even then, it's probably impossible.

So, broken classes (Squire is better than everything by far) + a broken business model (charging people for the game for over a year and then suddenly making it free to play, prioritizing skins and selling in-game currency over actually progressing the game to a conclusion and taking it out of Early Access) + broken servers (lagging in my private tavern, connecting to the public tavern happens once in a while) = not recommended.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Unlike it's predecessor, Dungeon Defenders 2 features a bunch of new qualities -- such as separate mana for abilities and towers, and a huger tavern.
Now, the graphics may be more attractive than the first game, but this DD2 quickly gets downgraded with it's slowly slithering 'pay to play' standards. Costumes in the previous one were able to be achieved through quests and fun game types, whereas in DD2 you must pay. Also, to open chests which include 'oh-so-rare' loot, you must buy keys.

It's a good tower defense game, but definitely something that gets old faster than Dungeon Defenders 1 -- you'll get bored from the inability of accessing cooler items in the game.

Early Access Review

Here I'll give you my opinion on the game.

I never played DD1, and I got this game 7 months ago. I did help Trendy beta test a game they were working on (Monster Madness Online) internally, so I did learn a lot about how they work, and manage things, ect.

First things first, you can expect constant updates and changes if they don't like how something is working, this company works very hard on their games, and they aren't here to just sell the game in early access and then throw up their hands and stop working on it. This is one game you can buy and know for sure that things will always be getting added/changed, ect.

So what can you expect yourself to be doing in this game? Well at the beginning you will be doing the Campaign, it's basically a long tutorial with a bit of a story to it, unless you/your group fails the zone, you won't be replaying the same area more than once during this Campaign, you will amass a ton of loot and after each zone, I like to replace/sell whatever items I've gotten. Once you've finished the campaign you will be doing higher difficulty" zones

reviewText:
Early Access Review

At first I'm talking about other people's responses to DD 2 and how DD 1 is with grinding compared to DD 2, so skip to paragraph 3 for the review.

First of all, everyone seems to hate this leveling system. They say it's all grinding, and its stupid, and that DD 2 should be just like DD 1. Now heres the truth, these people just dont remember the beggining of DD 1. Sure you could beat the set of levels to proceed to the next 3, but guess what? Usally those levels were IMPOSSIBLE for your level! Sure Sure, you could say that you just needed skill in tower defense to win, but remember how you unlocked toweres? By grinding! Not just a little grinding, ALOT of ginding. For me atleast I thought it was alot of grinding. So then I play through the story, replaying the same levels over, and over again until I win. Then guess what? I was level 30, so all the challenges were ♥♥♥♥♥ IMPOSSIBLE! I had to gind to 50 to have a chanse at those. I went hell no, and downloaded the DLC. I invited my buddy over to play and guess what? It was impossible for a level 30. So you know what I did? I grinded my ♥♥♥ of. So please dont tell me DD 2 is a grind fest, because DD 1 beats it sooooo far out of the ballpark, it's in a whole new planet. All these people remember is the end game, but there was a incredibly long grind to victory.

Now lets talk more about DD 2 way of handling levels. You start in the 1-3 level select. With my three characters it takes one game to unlock more levels, therefore in the 3-5 group. I play another game and I'm not there so I play an online match to get levels faster and boom I unlock another (this time set) of levels. See the way this works? The game is just helping you through the grind with you having to sometimes replay levels to level up, instead of giving you a level your 10 levels off beating, then you keep getting to the last wave and crying when you wasted 30 minutes of your life. Then I have to grind previous levels, then every level replay it until I'm stroung enough. This is more of a way to let you know if your stroung enough. Could it not force you to not play those levels... well yes but you'll die anyways so I dont really care.

Now on to the review side of these DD 2 has some proublems. First I wish there was a story, but oh well it's only pre-alpha and it will be added later. (plus, who play DD 1 for the story any way?.) Next is the glitches. Theres a wierd teleporing all over the map/tavern glitch that keeps happening, but again it's in pre-alpha so what did you expect? Third point is that while weapons and shields change with loot, the armour never changes and I REALLY what this to change because I'm disencoureged to find armour when that new sword will be flaming, or that new staff have a crystal with mist around it. Kind of a knit pick but, it does effect how I play so I put it here. (plus this game is so good I don't have many knit picks, and im the biggest knit picker I know.) Lastly is a good and bad thing that won't apply to everyone. You have a character deck for who you can switch out in between waves like in DD 1, only the limit is 3. So if your like me and levels all 4 characters, say good bye to one or later when theres DLC but 2 other characters and cobine them with your left out choice. This may not affect most people because they have only one character, but I had to say good-bye to my monk... for now.

Now the good things, aww yeah. Lets start with the obvious, the GRAPHICS ARE SO GOOD. I mean like INCREDIBLY good levels of good. Set this game to high and you won't be sorry. Also EVERYTHING look 10 times beter from background, to envirment, to the glourious loot, to my favorites the characters and enemys. My good good there so detailed, the goblins which are the weakest trash enemys of the game are so detailed, clearly someone spent countly mounths perfecting each design to make it just perfect. AND THIS IS IN PRE-ALPHA! Not even the full game yet!

Next good thing is the level design. DD 1 was good, even amazing, but this is borderline pefection. I mean it there was some clearly good designers here. You all deserve a cookie, wait no a pie. Infact I'm coming to Trendy with pies for everybdy, unless there to busy prefecting more enemy's and loot. Next is the new lines that show the path of all the enemys. Thats right, theres no more comlaing that you lost because you didnt know a enemy ogre could go there, or a pack of colbots went another direction you didnt expect. (I HATE COLBOLTS! I take it back, goblins arn't all trash I take it all back.)

The next thing amazing about this game is what was in my opinion, not that solid in DD 1, the combat. In DD 1 the combat was simple, press button alot in a swarm of enemy's and when you lose to much health (which im garunteeing you will in survival mode on mave 15) go and heal. The best thing about combat was the  ogers, but they were so slow you just have to back off while they attack and go in for the kill after the attack. Simple, and with a friend you could trick the AI shooting at him from both sides, and therefor confusing him making him turn around alot. Then the ninjas were stupid, would lose me all the time, and shouldnt be in DD 1 in the first place. In DD 2 It's much better. First off all death has a big consenquense. when you die your dead for a LONG while instead of 10 seconds, so dont ever die. Next healing costs alot of blue gems and takes a long time. So don't get hurt, because theres a consequense unlike the DD 1 where you wait 2 seconds to heal. The combat its self is more balenced so squire wont steal all the kills like in DD 1, and most importantly the enemy AI is good in combat. They are worthy opponets and running in with a sword to a giant lizard (forgive me I forgot there name.) Will hurt alot or kill you unles you sheild ALOT or back away at the right time, and shooting the lizards is just as hard because you'll have a arrow (or mana) vs acid the giant lizard is spitting. And thats just one enemy. Trust me, the AI is better.

Next is the class balencing issues with DD 1, Squire is way to Over Powered, Wizard is Over Powered and has mana bomb, Monk is balenced with nothing good or bad about him, and huntess us Under Powered with long reloades. On the other hand DD 2 made everyone good in there own way, and the huntress is even one of the three people in my main deck.

Next is the defenses themselves for each character are more balenced but if your solo, you need the wizards or squires blockades. The best thing about the new defenses this time is there alot more fun, like the guyser the sendes enyemes flying in the air for you to shoot. There really cool, and the huntress traps have way more ammo.

I'm going to stop here because this review would go on forever but i'll start the conclusion. If you love DD 1 you'll love this game but remember, there is a little grinding that you may of forgot from all that time in the end game. If your new I would wait until this becomes free to play, with DLC on the way. I say this because there is no tutorial for newbies, however if your new and your friend is begging for  you to play now I HIGHLY recommend this. Play with ypur friend a little while and you'll soon get the game inside and out. I want to cut this short so message me if you have any questions about thing like level count, loot, ect. Hope this helped :) Thanks for reading!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game is just so bland and unoriginal.
In their previous game each hero actually had a selection of towers to defend with. Here you get 4 for each but expect to only be using like one or two of them.

I liked the monk in the first game so I picked him again here. My job is to put up boost auras on each tower and then baby sit them all. My lightning field just doesn't help all that much and it's much better to just boost the mages fire tower.

So the strat me and my brother have been using it. Mage shield, mage fire tower and then boost aura. Every single time we played it. Not even the slightest hint of being able to change anything with the setup.
It's boring, soul crushingly boring.

Also you basically get up the setup on the first and second round and after that it's mainly buffing up the towers.


Tl:dr version: Developers added bare minimum in terms of towers and variation and it's making the game pretty damn boring.

Get Orc Must Die 1 and 2 if you want a quality Tower Defense game. Some actual planning in those two games.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nDungeon Defenders use to be a simple, rpg-ish, tower defense game that you can play with a group of friends on a couch or online. Now, it is online only. In DD1, with a push a button, you can see your tower set. Push another button, you can repair or heal yourself/towers. Now, you have to push a few more buttons to repair or heal. I like the look of the game and the fact you can build towers without needing to be there anymore but the tower placing, equipment, and attacking are completely different. Control tutorials dont change when a controller is connected. So good luck finding out how to ready up or build towers with a controller when they say hit G. I don't recommend this yet but have high hopes they don't require us to buy gems to progress like most F2P games.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is coming from a DD1 fan who played it for a few years non stop.

Yes it's not exactly like the original, but thats the good thing about it, who would want an exact clone of DD1 after all this time? Now I am not saying that DD1 is bad, It's brilliant, but personally I think DD2 shines where DD1 failed to do so.

Yes it is a bit cheesy that they are selling the same charachters again for dlc, but remember, it IS free to play.

If you have played this game when it was pay to play, let me reasure you that it is almost a different game, everything is alot smoother and flows better.

One of the only things I am dissapointed in is the lack of upgrading items and pets at low level, which in my opinion let players get used to it before choosing a pet was the most important thing in the game.

Another is the lack of harder difficulties on low level players, I love a challenge and was dissapointed to see that the hardest difficulty for my noob mage was Normal. What happened to trying to beat The Deeper Well on Insane level 1 char only?

This game is definantly worth getting since it is an amazing game, if i were to put a price on it, I would say around $15-$20 AUD. but since its free there is no reason not to give this a spin.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Just remember this is an Early Access Review and does not refer to the game in it's completed state.

Dungeon Defenders, the game before the sequel, in it's entirety was completely awesome and great.
When the game started, there wasn't a whole lot of DLC and stuff added to it just yet. The difficulty of the game for starters was not easy and it took time to learn how to play.

The same can be said about Dungeon Defenders II currently. It's difficult, it isn't easy to learn, and there isn't ANY DLC just yet. However, this is currently an Early Access Game and it isn't the end of it's expansion. Currently I would recommend this game to be played with friends and you will have a fun time exploring the new maps, learning the new mechanisms, and enjoying the overall gameplay with friends.

This game singleplayer is not recommended at all because it requires alot of strategy and time to understand the complexity of the new set of towers and defenses, finding out what works for you. You only get 3 heroes overall per map (unless there is more in later levels or something) and you can only do certain maps and difficulties in a particular level range so power-leveling your characters is not really that much of an option.

Having more people on your team also gives you a better chance at an item bonus so working with 3 other people aside from yourself is the most ideal way to make it through every map and level range. This game is a great multiplayer game and is far superior to Dungeon Defenders when it first started out. It is more balanced and fair and it makes the game a little more challenging and competitive.

Anyone who does not like this game only doesn't like it for the fact that the game isn't done.
This is an Early Access Game and it isn't completely finished. They haven't even brought out the PvP just yet and they are already complaining about the Co-Op. All the heroes have not been released yet and it certainly makes for an interesting game to watch come into development.

Highly recommended.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nDungeon Defenders 2 is in pretty playable condition for having the tag 'pre-alpha', and it is filled with a decent amount of content to keep coming back to. The Devs are constantly listening to what users what and are responding in a positive fashion. This game has to live up to the high standards of that Dungeon Defenders One, but i feel the game is on the right path. The loot system is much better than the 1st game series and the towers have a refreshing appeal, especially since you can now combine elements to increase damage or efficiency. It is a great game to play with friends, and hopefully the game will live up to the standards of Dungeon Defenders One.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

DUNGEON DEFENDERS 2
I personally CANNOT STOP PLAYING THIS GAME. To be honest, I was extremely skepticle on whether or not it would be worth my $14.99 for, and it's not (Maybe), but I got it off another site Steam keeps blocking with a Four-Pack for $2.49, completely worth it. I did however buy the Collectors Edition to show my support for this beautiful game. But enough bantering, here's the Game in a Nutshell.

MECHANICS
Dungeon Defenders 2 plays like a Tower Defense with a complete twist of Four characters you play in 3rd person, all with their own Abilities and Towers, Strengths and Weaknesses. Your 4 Heroes are The Apprentice (WHY NOT CALL IT THE MAGE?), Squire (AGAIN, WHY NOT CALL IT A KNIGHT?), Huntress, and Monk. All have their own good Synergies with the other Heroes.

The Apprentice is a good Form of DPS, Squire is a Tank, Huntress makes Traps that Synergize well with all other Heroes, and the Monk uses Buffs and Debuffs for your Team.

ENDGAME
This game probably has a lot of Life ahead of it, despite being in Alpha for a year, the Devs listen to their Community, and have made the Game extremely long for anyone looking to do a Completionist run on it.

OVERALL REVIEW
This game is Beautifully made, but make sure you have a good enough computer for it, sometimes the particles can make your game lose framerate. All in all, buy the game, either on Steam to support them or get the Value price of 2.49 on a site steam keeps blocking, which I recommend. 11/10 would buy four pack again on a site that Steam keeps blocking because the site sells games for very low prices and is trusted... (See my Profile page for the Site name, because Steam blocks the name.)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So very minimal gameplay at time of writing this. Only played the first few maps.
There is a fair few bugs, which unless you can identify them, it will stop your progress (enemies glitched inside of walls in small corners, death seems to disable the 'ready up' button, etc)

I also noticed the price of DLC, and holy crap! There should be a way to earn them in-game or something, not flog out up to $50USD just for some skins and a title...

Other than that, gameplay is basically left MB = attack (can be held for infinite attacks), right MB (hold down) = bigger attack.
Easy difficulty is super easy and Normal is basically an instant match loss (from the times I tried it). Seems a tad unbalanced.

As current, I can not recommend this game, due to repetitive and far too simple gameplay and super expensive DLC.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------
I must say though, I LOVE the weapon designs!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I was an avid Dungeon Defenders 1 player and loved so many things about that game.  Dungeon Defenders 2 is a far cry from a sequel to do it justice.  While 2 does have its few improvements, most of what they have tried to do and the changes they have made just fall well short of 1.

I do have to say that I PAID for early access and now this game has become Free To Play which I think is not at all a good thing.  Cheated with no reward.

Comparisons of 1 and 2:
-The size, scale, and scope of the levels are very dissapointing compared to 1.  The maps are small wiith no real options for strategy, just put down big towers and hit the mobs as soon as they exit the doors or just barricading the crystal.  Towers seem too big and bulky on most maps.
-Character depth and selection is so much less than 1.  Why do so many changes and break a great stat and equipment system?  Less skills, less stats, less customization, less options, big part of what made 1 great which is gone in 2.
-Sloppy developement in a lot of ways.  Parts of the game, which were disabled from early beta, have just been abandoned in place, or left not working and broken.  Glaring glitches, major errors, updates that break the game, cumbersome control and gameplay (ex. can't use controller due to faulty button mappping on programmer side), major lag and sluggishness on normal game operations and loading which suggests a bare minimum approach to developement.

I would say that they have a long way to go before this early access build is anything like Dungeon Defenders 1.  I don't feel the experience is anywhere near as good.  While I would love to help develope this game towards that direction, I don't think Trendy's direction is a good one at the moment.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've played the first one, it was great fun. This second one does a fantastic job building on what was great. Keeping what made it successful, yet deepening the gameplay, and setting itself up to become a very successful and long lasting experience.

I've played the Pre-alpha so far, these days with so many Early Access floating around on steam, very few are actually entertaining for long periods of time and don't portray a very good picture of what the end product will be like.

After purchasing it (based on the gameplay I've seen, and my experience of the first game) I read up on some of the difficulties the Studio faced, and as a member of a fellow game studio, I can understand their struggles, but I also commend them for making the right decisions to make the game they want to make for their fans.

What I didn't know was that DD2 is intended to become a Free-to-play game. Even though I bought into it (with a 4 pack) which I think will work really well if done correctly, and it sounds like they got their heads on straight.

I fully intend to cover this game in my future video guides, as I feel there may be enough depth to the game to make regular videos for fans.

But one tip I can share right off the bat: PLAY WITH FRIENDS. It is infinitely more enjoyable, especially if you're around the same level. The matchmaking system is probably still in the works, so do yourself the favour, and don't expose yourself to potential malicious players who could ruin your experience. You payed good money, a good experience will allow you to justify it's current Early Access cost.

Keep it up Trendy, you all deserve it!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's not a great game and honestly it's a step back from the original. However, DunDefToo does grow on you a bit. Finding rare loot and pets feels nice... but loot is so overabundant that you stop caring about anything that isn't mythic/legendary. The game has an auto-collection feature but it doesn't let you choose what is collected/left behind. This means you gotta sift through the garbage to make sure you didn't miss a pet or pet food (they don't have an indicator on the screen/map to make them easy to track).

The maps are all super boring, small, and mostly tight spaces. This is problematic because players and towers have collisions on them. So, the game gets crowded very quickly.

Players get their own mana (currency for making/repairing/upgrading defenses) each round and it scales based on the player count. This is pretty nice and you can hand it off to the other players. Sadly, the game is totally anti-social. A single player can (like the first game) change their character to place additional defenses. The players also have a shared point limit for placing defenses. So, most of the time you either put up with bad placements or a single player doing everything. Basically, the game stops being tower defense and more about doing nothing or going combat focused (killing things yourself). This was a problem in the first game as well, but those maps were usually laid out in a way that a combat player still retained value.

The pet system is god awful. You need special materials to evolve" your pets... this sounds cool
date: but you need a resource called "shellium" which is obtained by letting pet eggs expire. This means you have to give up the chance at an interesting pet for some resources... and it takes 48 hours of sitting in your inventory to expire. Pets occupy their own special bag space
recommended: but eggs take up normal bag slots. Leveling up pets requires food... food does not stack with itself and therefore takes up extra bag space. The eggs can be hatched instantly between matches (in the tavern after you reach a certain level)
hoursPlayed: but the timers could change. The timers used to be 8 hours and you can only hatch one at a time.\n\nSo
voteText:
your inventory will consist of the following:
* Garbage items for upgrades/selling
* Eggs
* Cosmetic item boxes (requires premium or daily quests to open)... you'll get a lot of these.
* Quality items (so you can use a different build.
* Pet Food
* Pet Food
* Pet Food

If you want to get materials to upgrade pets then you'll spend even more space on eggs.

What the game sells for a premium:
* Character slots (5$) - you get enough for each class at leas
* Bags - 2-5$ depending on the size of the bag
* Pet Bags - 2-3.5$ depending on the extra space you want
* Costumes - 10$ or more for costumes
* Pet Skins - 2$ or more depending on the costume

At first glance the game seemed pretty fair (monetization-wise)... but with the inventory problems and sheer cost of space it began to feel greedy. Like they sacrificed usability to sell more things.


Physics/Networking:
So
helpfulPercent: the game is prolly hosted on a server rather than on the leader's system. This wouldn't be so bad
votesHelpful: but the game's server is authoritative and the client has to obey. This means rubberbanding
votesTotal: or worse
votesFunny: the server sends you flying forward because it didn't notice that you had stopped. This means that input lag exists... and it's pretty awful. It's like they built the game on an old-school architecture without realizing that there are superior options.\n\nThe game has large
commentsCount: blocky
column16: collisions for everything. The characters slide (prolly input lag) around and so it's not uncommon to throw yourself off of a cliff. When your character attacks they move a little bit and the animation can't be canceled. This again
column17: leads to the feeling of input lag (this is animation related rather than server related though). Basically
column18:
ranged attacks function better than melee attacks.

Bottom line:
It's a skinner box disguised as a game... a game with poor physics and networking. While it's free-to-play it has a lot of greedy elements hidden in there."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Dozens of unique maps, people only ever play the one that they know is the fastest loot farm. It's literally impossible to find a group through matchmaking anywhere else.

Join a group, watch one guy build all the towers and then sit around doing nothing while you wait for loot. You can run up and hit the monsters if you want, but it gets boring quickly when you realize that they die to towers just the same even if you ignore them.

The only way to actually participate and feel useful is if you solo. But once you've figured out a working setup, it's still just a matter of building the towers and waiting for the enemies to die, then doing it over and over exactly the same hundreds of times until you have all the best loot and nothing left but to wait for a patch to bring some new tier of gear.

Many many people have mentioned these issues on the official forums. Trendy acknowledged the complaints and said they would be addressed, but all we ever get are new costumes and slightly different weapon varients. It's time to admit that this game is as good as it's going to get, and right now it's not worth wasting your time on.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Albeit I have only played for a short while, I have gotten a clear picture how this game works, and even though it is very similar to the first game, this one takes the simple idea and then tosses it in a river.

The RPG, loot collecting, and tower defense, is fun as ever. However, when you first start off playing the game, you are met with utter confusion. The first maps start off as hard as most maps were half way through the game in the first game. By the way I reached the third or fourth map; It had four places where monsters kept pouring out, and the items I were to defend were placed in a haphazard manner. The maps are in general just poorly designed in comparison to the first game.

So, right from the start; This game is impossible to play alone to get a hang of it. So you are forced to play with people online, which I figured is the way it's supposed to be played, of course. Well, it would have made a bit more sense to let a person who is new to the game actually start off in a brand new game, and not throw the poor player into a group that is already half-way through the map, leaving you unable to build any towers. So you stand alone in the onslaught, doing no damage, simply waiting to get your free loot.

Also, throwing all the leveling info, stats, customization, and everything of the sort ALL AT THE SAME TIME, is extremely daunting and off-putting. Slowly introducing mechanics to new players would be extremely helpful, since most info you get is either too detailed or not detailed at all.

It's not a terrible game by all means. But it would at most get 4 out of 10, where the original DD would easily get 8 out of 10. If it was as simple to learn as its predecessor, the game would have been better in general. But the useless stats thrown around, no proper info or pointers given, poor optimization, and the maps being completely rubbish in comparison to the first game, does make it feel extremely lackluster.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

6/10

For those who have invested many many many hours into the first Dungeon Defenders, heed my warning. This game is very much worse than the first Dungeon Defenders. It just does not offer much in comparison but since it is free (open alpha), feel free to try it out yourself.

I personally enjoyed this game a fair bit.
This game was also very fun playing with friends and theory crafting strategies for beating maps we were having trouble on. Figuring out the most effective/efficient tower placements made it quite fun the first time around.

After the initial 50 hours I started to grow quite boring and tedious to do anything and everything.
The journey of getting your first max level character (level 50 at this point in time) is probably the most fun I've had in this game. Getting to max level and grinding out for the best gear you can and then replacing it instantly after climbing to the next Nightmare difficulty becomes less and less rewarding and feels like more of a chore.

With everything I've said, this game is fairly fun for the first 30-50 hours.
In that time you can:
-Learn about the classes
-You can reach max level on a character or two (or 3 if you're really diligent)
-Learn about every map

F I N A L   V E R D I C T
All the maps are given to you and you can play them all before you ever reach max level.
There is no real reward to reaching max level besides being able to start the Nightmare difficulties which are just a pain the butt and offer nothing new besides identitcal weapons with better overall stats.
You get the feeling of Oh great now I get to grind the same maps but its even harder...woop dee friggin' doo"

I give it a rating of 6/10 and I'm listing it as a positive review because I did indeed have a lot of fun. It just gets boring with the lack of variety in "End Game""

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Review for Players of DD1 and DDE
Dungeon Defenders 2 is the sequel to Dungeon Defenders 1 and Dungeon Defenders Eternity. However even though being a sequel this game couldn't be more diffrent. As a veteran in DD1 and DDE I'll have to say this game isnt the same, but that doesn't make the game less fun. Everthing has been reworked from Enemies all the way to Heros. Heros have gotten new Abillitys and Towers, however keeping the old themes of the Heros. As of now the 4 basic Heros and Series EV have been brough back along side an all new Character the Abyss Lord. The Abyss Lord is a rework a the old Summoner.
Difficulty curve in this game is alot diffrent aswell. Still featuring Easy to Nightmare, however Nightmare 1 to 4 each being more difficult.
Something verteran players will notice over the course of the game is that Item stats have been changed alot. Instead of featuring upto 10 stats, Items will now feature 3 stats and upto 3 passives. Also not to mention the Defense Speed stat has been removed from items and can only be skilled with Stat points from leveling up.

DD2 is somewhat recommendable to old veterans.

Review for all new Players to Dungeon Defenders
Dungeon Defenders 2 is a 4 player cooperative Tower Defense RPG. Unlike most Tower Defense games you do not just sit arround and watch your towers defend, no you actually get to make a diffrence yourself with your Heros.
This game features 5 diffrent heros (more to come) each being unique in their own way.
The story of this game has an playtime of about 50 hours. However the overall game has an playtime of over 400 hours.
After completing the Story your hunt to reach the highest level and Item Power begins in order to take part the the most difficult challenges of the game.
This game features a very balanced loot system that almost always ends up with you finding better items. However grinding gear is still a thing.
DD2 does feature mircrotransactions to keep the game alive however they are just cosmetic.

Keep in mind that this game is in Alpha (at the point of this review) and alot of features in this game a subject to change. I'll keep my opinion on the game updated as updates come and go.

Overall I would recommend this game to anyone who loves Tower Defenses.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

To be quite honest, I DO RECOMMEND THIS GAME FOR THOSE WHO HAVE PLAYED DD1 AND LOVED IT. It's great, but there are multiple problems that you would commenly expect when getting a pre-alpha game. Ignoring the fact that I have down voted this game, there are multiple aspects of this game that include DD1 gameplay style and newly intergrated styles in this new game.

Now for the main reasons I have (not) recommended this game.

- A lot of the features of DD1 have been removed/rehased/recycled. This means that some of the things have been kept, while some of these things have been reworked, while most of the other stuff has been reused.

-Style of the game is great, it is visualy appealing and very well textured/graphics are amazingly good for a pre-alpha.

- A lot of the classes have been reworked and nerfed heavily. Huntress's mines/traps and bombs area of effect has been greatly nerfed had has no were near the the effect they did in DD1. Squire's defences are while the same, have been heavily nerfed, and dont hold a candle to DD1's squire's defences. Monk and Apprentice are in the same boat, thus making the game a lot more difficult and challenging when progressing onwards in leveling. Defences are also quite weak, and you're forced to rely on your hero to do most of the cleaning of waves.

-Mana: Mana has been drastically altered and is no longer the main currency of the game. While you still use mana to build towers and use abilities, the new incorperation of a coin/gold system is now the new money of the game. Speaking of mana, there are two different types of mana. Ability mana (Blue) and Tower mana (Green) both drop off enemies, but in very LOW quantites.

-Online system: They have a very strange working of the Online/Server set up which at first greatly confused me. However it took a while to get use to. You are thrown into a recruitment tavern where you talk to a recruiter. This brings up a menu allowing you to pick from multiple different level groups. E.g. 1-5. 5-10. 10-15. This also stops boosting somewhat as if you were a higher level, (E.g. 15) and joined a lower level bracket, (E.g. 5-10), you would be brought down to level 10 for the remainer of your time in that bracket, once you leave, you are returned to your normal level. This also kicks lower level characters from trying to join higher level brackets.

Overall, the game is very different from DD1. I was expecting it to be a lot better than the first one, and wasn't expecting much of the workings of the characters to change that much considering they were perfect in the first game. However this is my opinion and that doesn't mean much on the internet.

The main reason I am not recommending this game is becuase it's purely a pre-alpha and the the fact that its $24, (from New Zealand), is not really ideal. However, in another case, if you loved DD1 and want to give it a try, by all means, i would recommend it to you just becuase its a great start to a game that has LOADS of potential. However, definately needs work, and lots of changes.

~~TLDR~~
If you liked DD1, get it and see for yourself. If you haven't played DD1 or didn't like DD1, don't get it, becuase it's simply not worth $24 or whatever its going for in your country. Especially when rumour has it that on offical release its going to go Free 2 Play.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

FIRST OF ALL NOTE THAT THIS GAME IS ON EARLY ACCESS (PRE-ALPHA), MEANING ITS NOT A FULLY DEVELOPED GAME WITH NO BUGS AND ALL CONTENT AVAILABLE.

I played the original dundef and i liked dd2 just as much.

Keeping true to the original game, still blending the fun of tower-defense game with action rpg games, this sequel is just as fun, if not MORE fun than the original dundef. (And it's only on early access! Imagine when it's fully released!)

~PROS~
-Better Graphics (LMFAO wHo cAREAS Xd seriously.)
-Characters are more customizable with the new accessory patch!
-The new sphere skill tree is better than dd1's skill point system imo. + UBER SPEC !!! (game-changing spec for each classes towers.)
-4 HERO ABILITIES COMPARED TO DD1'S 2 HERO ABILITY.
-The world is more interactive (Pre-Set Traps!)
-Class COMBOES! water + electric = electrocute? oil + fire = ignite? yes please!

~CONS~
-The towers are BOOORING. I miss the bowling ball turret from DD1 T_T
-BUGS GLITCH BUGS GLITCH (But it's okay, since its only Pre-Alpha.
-NEED MORE HEROES!
-Some Spec is just utter 5H!T AND USELESS. MORE CHARACTER SPEC PLZ!!!
-♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ AI GETS STUCK AND IT PISSES ME OFF! (Could be exploited too, but what fun would that be?)

Overall, the game's progess is looking REAAAAL good. I was skeptical about buying it first, but then Trendy really showed me their hard work on making this game, even convincing me to buy the collector's edition (DAMMIT TRENDY!)

9/10.

HIGHLY RECOMMEND PLAYING THIS WITH YOUR FRIENDS! Soloing is possible, but it gets BOOORING REAL FAST, but if you play this game with your friends (4 stack if possible) it is just simply AMAZING.

<3 u Trendy, keep up the good work!

-Popon

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Alpha & Beyond: It's looking great. It runs rather well, I have expirienced very few to no bugs at all and the Devs are quick to fixing any that happen to pop up. The classes are all fairly balanced in their own ways and they're all able to be built about 2-3 different ways, which adds some more diversity to the game itself.

That being said, it is till only in Alpha stage so there is a rather large limit to most of the game's features at the moment. After completing the Campagin mode you're left with Free mode and a newer insane mode, which both become repetitive and annoying at times, especially with having only so many maps to play.

Good news is that the community is alot kinder than most and if you don't mind replaying maps here and there it can become addicting, and one hell of a lootfest. With the many ways of playing classes and spending 8 hours a day waiting for the damn eggs to hatch just one legendary pet to admire; you'll get alot of time into it. It's also possible to play singleplayer, if you're the anti-social type or just don't have any friends.

All in all, it's a fairly good game for being in Early access, and there's clearly alot more coming to the game. So if you don't mind the repetitive gameplay and watching the game grow, then this is for you. If you'd rather get the full expirience then go ahead and wait, either way this certainly is, and most likely will be a wonderful game upon full release.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

-This review may get some future edits-

Apparently there is few bad reviews for this game, and I notice the reason for that probably is because they don't find the game similar to first DD1 and to have different aspects. As far as I can see those folks didn't even play the game enough to make such harsh reviews of the game, they simply give up after having to do some grind, which is sad cuz the game is very promising and fun.

To begin with I must say that I never did any review about an early-access or beta/alpha games, but well ... like they say : there is always a first time.

So here we go. The first Dungeon Defenders games come out a couple of years ago, and I never had a chance or time to try them out on that time. Just this year I had a chance to play it and without any surprises I immediately loved it.

After getting all the collection I decided to also buy the upcoming Dungeon Defenders II, which is currently on alpha (I probably will update this review later), but for now the game is running really GOOD, So good that doesn't even feel like an early-access, As you can notice I got tons of hours already, that's all because the game hook you in, lots of fun playing solo or online, and will be even better when this goes F2P, cuz all your friends will be able to play it without spend a cent. Though I really reccomend this game as it is right now because it worth every penny.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Lets try to make this quick. I have played DD but not DDE.
This review is also written from Pre-Alpha. (7-30-2015, [m-dd-yyyy])
Also I have only play Monk lvl 25 and Apprentice (Mage) lvl 15~
Pros:
+Great gameplay, smooth and good flowing combat feel
+Matchmaking better than it was in DD1
+Funny story line, Most NPCs even though 1 liners right now I already feel like they have some sort of tale to tell
+Loot loot loot. (sometimes too much?)
+Keeps the cartoon style of DD1 but slim and tall instead of short and stalky
Bias+ I enjoy the pet system of having to hatch your pet from an egg, feels more of a pet than equipment
Cons:
-Still early access ofc
-Premium currency? even if it isn't P2W so far (It is looking like $1 = 100 runes and cheapest skins are 400, 800, and 1600 runes so skins are not extremely expensive and a nice way to support the devs)
-Once you get about the last 5 campaign lvls its hard to find people playing them in MM
-You have to finish campaign before dailies/monthly (this is only con because its hard to find people for last 5 missions)

Conclusion:
Buy this game if you're interested and have the money. If it is on sale just buy it you'll enjoy at least a few hrs of play.

This game is still in Pre-Alpha which for most games out there it looks pretty much done. For full price of $24.99 It is worth the 11hrs I've played so far. (The week I write this it is on mid-week madness sale of $15) The only bugs I've really had to deal with in my hrs of play is the Drakins will get stuck on small senery and they update almost every time I want to play :P
Edit: After about 20-30 minutes of posting this review I had a DEV! comment. A++ they're asking players how the game is and getting our feedback to know how to make it better. I can no longer recomend this game more now. If you enjoy any kinds of games that are cartoony and/or dungeony and/or deffending Buy this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Having played the this game's predecessor: Dungeon Defenders 1 it's great to see Trendy is trying to fix some of the issues that plagued the previous title, while staying true to the great foundations of the Defenders series.

Combat is easy to get into and unlike the previous title the hero abilities feel like they make a difference in combat, not only does this make battles more exciting it also gives you a compelling reason to invest in ability specs instead of heading straight for hero damage and health like in the previous game.

Tower placing has improved vastly since the previous game, and feels more balanced in terms of green mana being available - in the previous title towers were able to reach their maximum upgrade level fairly quickly, however in DD2 mana is more scarce so upgrades need to be more tactical and always repairs are essential at all times. Some towers in the game have combinations but the squire class seems to have been left out of this equation - something I hope the developers are planning on addressing.

Loot is more fair in this title, in the previous game loot was dropped and visible to all players, this would lead to a mad scramble as everyone abandoned their posts to try and snatch the loot before someone else. In Dungeon Defenders 2, loot is instanced (players can only see their own loot) and means that people focus more on the battle than watching for a nice drop. Nice drops are also alerted to so people don't have to stare at the map all the time.

However a lot of the game is still missing, I'd like to see:
* More bosses
* Improved pet system
* Higher level cap (as content comes)
* More game modes
* Balanced uber spec spheres
* A way of selling unused spec spheres
* More adventure maps

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I am really enjoying Dungeon Defenders 2, I am a fan of Dungeon Defenders and have had the second game on my wishlist for a while now.  Overall I feel like the game has improved, it lacking a lot of things the first game had at the moment but it is still in alpha. I am jsut glad i dont have to deal with all those crazy hacks and mods i feel like were rampant on the first game.

For those not familiar with Dungeon Defenders, you chose your hero and battle waves of enemy's in tower defense gameplay with up to four friends. Dungeon Defenders has a good deal of classes to chose, but so far in Dungeon Defenders 2 we only have the 4 original to chose from, those being the Huntress, squire, monk, and apprentice.

Really I am hoping that Dungeon Defenders 2 ends up better than the first game. Its supposed to be going free to play after launch so I am really hoping it  gets popular. its a fun tower defense game, especially if you play with friends.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As with any Early Access game, make sure it is a game you are okay with it being changed as development goes on. As it stands, the game plays very similar to the first, with some minor changes. So far it seems to be living up to the greatness that was Dungeon Defenders 1.

Understand that because it is early access, I know a lot of my concerns with the game will be fixed, and I will update my review when that happens.

Pros/Cons:

+ The AI seems to be smarter, and more dificult than those in the first game.
+ The ability to move your hero while in place/repair/upgrade defense mode is amazing.
+ The Dual Mana system is also an awesome addition. You now have mana for abilities, and a separate mana for towers.
+ The new defenses each hero has are either upgrades from the first game, or new all together, which is good.
+ The ability to vote for the next addition into the game is an awesome early access feature, and should be done more often by developers.
- The gear upgrade system is lacking, and confusing at first.
- There has yet to be added a proper tutorial system for new features.
- The small amount of maps gets old quite fast, and the game tends to get boring after a bit.
- Costumes and pets are nowhere to be found, and is one of the things that made the first game a favorite.
- The gear shops are barely useful, as the only reason I use them is to get junk gear to upgrade my current stuff.

All in all, the game is damn good, and can only get better from here.
voteText: 11 of 20 people (55%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A sequel to the wildly popular and unique Dungeon Defenders game that takes a different direction from its predecessor.

(Note, I originally did not recomment this game, but after hours of playing, I have decided to recommend it.  I'll explain why below.)

Pros
- Personal loot drops make for a more relaxed game where you don't have to constantly keep your eyes out for drops you need (There's no more race to grab the good loot before other players and that is a great design call)
- The classes have some really cool attacks and abilities making each feel unique
- Changes to mana and loot selling have made things much easier, both for sorting through loot and for upgrading it
- Seperation of mana for building and for personal powers was a great call
- Easy group finding system gets you right into the action
- Reputation system makes random players more inclined to be polite
- Synergy system means you can make powerful tower combinations if you have a cooperative team of players.

Cons
- Can't play offline
- Long lags between games.  Due to the fact that a game has no clear leader, everyone has to ready up for the game to progress between levels and after the games.  This doesn't sound too bad, but when people go afk or someone new isn't paying attention, it can end up being 2+ minutes to continue on
- Solo, each classes tower set is lacking (I'll explain more about this below)
- A lack of mana will prevent you from doing much during a combat round (at least at low level)
- The win points and fun-factor strategies to this game aren't as obvious as they were in the original
- Builder specs feel very nerfed thanks to the lack of mana (EDIT: Again, this is only when you don't try to work with the other player's towers)
- Maps are a bit bland, there aren't as many strategic points where you can put towers to have them cover multiple lanes
- Tower synergies are esential to effective play
- Certain specs are almost completely useless right now
- Gating low-level players means that you can't power level your buddies.  It also means that, if your buddies get too far ahead, you can't play with them unless you make a new character.
- Certain monsters outrange your towers.  I'm not sure if this changes at high level, but at low level it's extremely frustrating.  It means that you'll be babysitting your towers instead of being able to place them in different spots and trust them to do their job.
- Due to the fact that you have to babysit your tower clumps, you cannot solo most of the levels (At least as an apprentice)

So I went back and started playing as the monk with a friend who was playing the huntress, and I quickly figured out a pretty devistating combo that made the game much more playable.  I also figured out that one of my mages towers, while not super impressive when combined with his original towers, was extremely effective when combined with one of the monk's auras.

So it seems the devs are really pushing for cooperative gameplay in this one, the game almost feels more like WoW than it does Dungeon Defenders.  To be successful, each player must assume a certain role in their tower construction.  A group of apprentice towers isn't very effective, however an ice tower combined with an electric aura (monk) combined with a water geyser (hunter) is devastating.  The concept is fun when it works out, the big problem is that new players or stubborn players will often build whatever they want, effectively lowering your chances of success.  I feel like this sort of design choice needs to be combined with a matchmaking system that tries to put one of each class in a game together.  (Maybe this is already the design, I don't know, but I was often in games with several members of my own class.)

The good news is, I did start having a lot of fun once I figured out how the devs expected me to play.  However, I had to do a lot of digging to find that answer.  The game needs to guide its new players better so they know what's needed for victory and don't just build whatever, therebye frustrating the other people who are trying to work as a team.

Also, the game needs more towers and more tower synergies.  As of this review, there is one devastating tower/aura/trap combination and everything else is very meh.  Certain towers are very meh and pretty much un-needed.  This needs to be changed so that there are multiple metas (tower building combinations) showing up in the games instead of just 1 or 2.

In closing, the game is fun but very different from the first Dungeon Defenders.  You'll have the most fun when playing with friends, and you may want to watch some videos on how to effectively use your towers depending on your class.

* Update
So the game changes quite a bit at high level.  Once you get your gear established and start the process of farming, you pretty much only need one skilled builder (generally an apprentice or squire) to do the tower setup for the level.  To be honest, it is kind of grindy and not always fun.  And while finding new items to improve your stats can be fun, the actual gameplay isn't.  This may change once more maps are available and harder difficulties are provided.  I'm going to keep my recommendation for now as the game isn't bad and still has potential, but I'm really looking for some new kinds of juicy cooperative gameplay.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Still early days as I write this, but this game is shaping up to be a winner.
It is a great family co-op game.  It appeals to both men and women (at least in my family). All four of us play: father, mother, sister, brother.
It is cartoony, in a colorful fantasy setting.  Everyone has a character and is always active, yet we're in it together, planning  a joint strategy to  prevent the monsters from destroying our crystal.
DD2 is nice step up from the original DD.  The visuals are fantastic.  The interface seems more intuitive.
Please game developers, let's have more family friendly co-op games such as this one.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nOverall if you played, and liked DD1, then you will like 2. I especially liked that they separated building mana and ability mana so you aren't put in a position of being restricted from using abilities because you have to save up mana to upgrade every tower to the highest rank.  Their new rune system is nice as well to add some customization in terms of passive abilities.  The only down side that I can think of is that if you were one to completely neglect one stat and focus on others (i.e who needs health and attack when I plan on just using the character for towers?  Or vice versa.)  That you will still collect gear that has stats which affect them, but the stat bonus when gaining a level has been steamlined.  I personally don't mind it, but I do know there were people who would have multiple versions of the same character, one for building and one for combat.  One other feature that is nice is that the enemies per wave seem to be no longer dependent upon the number of players, thus the probability of someone booting you because they don't want more bad guys to fight per wave is no longer an issue.

Early Access Review

8/10

So far, so good. Great gameplay, extremely rare to come across bugs. Very nice and helpful community both in the game and on the forums. I'm guessing the old generation plays these kinds of games, I rarely meet any kids.

Everything runs extremely smoothly with graphics and whatnot, I would however wish they made it harder to level in the future, and do the drops for rare loot even more rare, it's easy to get good gear atm, or at least that's how I feel.

Easily worth the price, even with the low game-time I have. Would buy again.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Keeping in mind this is early release the game has great potential.
At its current state you get to a point and just aren't able to get needed upgrades.

Pros:
- on-key for new players
- follows a progressive map unlock system
- fun to play
- very easy to pickup the important concepts
- depth of play is above average

Cons:
- horrible party match system (end up in the same game which shouldn't even be possible unless you select to join the same one)
- lots of legendary drops but very few useful ones (less would be better if you get that 1 you need)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's still in early development but already quite playable. For the players familiar with DD1 it's a feast of recognition and for those new into the world of hybrid FPS combined with tower defenses" there's a tutorial and campaign easing you into the game.
At the moment of this writing there's only 4 characters available
date: the same foursome from the original. But in true spirit the characters have aged a bit and no longer look like grade-school Southpark aged characters but more like teenagers. Quite a nice detail giving you the feeling of story progression.\nThe game is still defend a crystal (see it as a homebase) from getting damaged by angry enemies. You can do this actively by killing them with your hero (the FPS element) or using your heroes defenses
hoursPlayed: explosive traps auras and walls/barriers.\nNot all is quite finished yet. The way xp evolves at the moment is still a bit unbalanced the same if you compare the ratio of hero damage versus the damage traps/towers do. At the moment there's lots of ways to share your feedback via the forum and the developers seems to take the feedback into account.\nIt's not a finished gem yet
voteText: but from what I can tell it plays a lot better than plenty of other "beta games" available on steam now.\nSo if you can live with a few issues and enjoy playing either solo (doable) or with friends (co-op) then this can be a fun game"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Have you played a tower defense game before?
- Of course it's grindy
- Of course it's repetitive

Dungeon Defenders 2 is an action hack n slash/tower defense.  It is a type of game that you play on a weekday afternoon for a couple of hours until you get sick of it. Then you do it again next week.

Those 10k dragon medals are simple to get.  Just play the game like a normal person.  I only played the game for a few hours these past 2 weeks and I didnt even realised I got 1.5k dragon medals.

People these days whine like babies on even the slightest hint of grind.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As of right now, it is lag nation... And since there is no single player option, even when playing solo you still LAG, its quite ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ indeed. Its an awesome game other then the lag though, so I will still recomend this beauty, just FIX THE LAG! Please :)

Some of the pros: Loot, lots and lots and lots of loots, and its not like you get amazing op gear fast, so its more like you have to work to get decent gear, which I personally enjoy.
Visually, this game is a real beauty in comparison to its predecessor.
Four diverse classes to choose from, and the ability to choose how you wish to play. You can focus your skill points into your character, or your characters defences (towers) or even go for a balanced build.

Cons: Already toxic community, but thats every f2p game right?
Lag, but again, thats expected from an initial alpha launch of a f2p game.
Lack of offline single player same with the lack of LAN play, this is a HUGE con for me as this is how I play 90% of the games I play, with my wife on LAN.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI'm surprised, to be honest. I bought every single bit of game changing content the previous Dungeon Defenders had, and loved the characters all the way. This dungeon defenders, though? It's a breed bought in microcontent and not even close to the original's quality. I am willing, nay eager, to pay $30-40 for a sequel - but I refuse to pay for gems, points, or widgets to make a lackluster base engine shine enough to make this work. From my play experience, I swear, it's like they farmed out design and even sensibility to a foreign country for cutthroat rates. I haven't spent a dime on the sequel, but I'm willing to chip in a fiver to pay for the tombstone of tedium for this developer group.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI saw some popular youtubers playing this game and was interested in trying it. The game crashed from the launcher and I used the developer's help page to make a ticket. After a couple emails and sending them a crash report, the response I received was that I was basically S.O.L. and that I would have to wait for a full release version for them to fix my problem. I'm pretty disappointed in this response. Hopefully others are not having the same problems, and I am definitely surprised as my system uses recent components.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

ungodly♥♥♥♥♥♥ servers, you load in without being able to open the box if you are in someones party, sometimes when you get disconnected and try to rejoin a party you enter with a phantom you in the party and fall continuously into infinity. You will have to exit the entire game and relog in to fix it.	♥♥♥♥♥♥ server coding that makes you use so much bandwidth to access any games it actually borks itself and makes you get a connection issue even after you are in the game. You can also get a match making error that pops up when you try to leave a party. So...yes. You get a connection issues for leaving the server host? ha. When you are in a game and change characters it has a random occurance to kick you out and tell you your login session expired and you have to restart the game to play. It will also do this on other occurances that tell you someone else is logged into your account. Sometimes your spheres won't equip and the network inconsistency makes it so you have to try and try until it works. When you switch characters some of the previous models will be stuck inside the other characters.
There are a million problems with this game yet content is being released over the absolute nonexistence of server stability. For a game on unreal you would expect it to run better, but no. No it doesn't. Needless to say there is alot of content to observe! This is the kind of roller coaster of a game where it's so fun you go again even though the sick guy in the front keeps puking all over everyone. when you are ending a map and getting the chest if you change characters it has a 3in5 chance to randomely kill you.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Developer: Trendy Ent.

Publisher: Trendy Ent.

Genre: Action Tower Defence



The emperor of the Action Tower Defence games is back. Help your friends, build towers, auras and traps; repair and upgrade 'em. Get back to endless waves of ♥♥♥ kicking fun!

In the first installation of the series, we were playing as the Little Defenders ( sons and daughters of the real heroes). These little heroes defended the Eternia Crystals and put an end to the Evil's plans but just when these littlelings lost all their power and hopes at the end of the first game, their beloved parents came to rescue at the right time and defeat the evil of the evillest.

With Dungeon Defenders II, the developers giving us the Real" heroes and their real adventures. Oracular graphics
date:
incredible character models and wondrously designed maps and gameplay mechanics that mostly operating like cogwheels; these are also what they are throwing at us. And as a Early Access it stand out like a sore thumb among others.

Lets start with seperating facts of DD1 and DD2:

-DD1 adopted the simplest co-op game formula; buy the game and its ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ of DLC's. DD 2 will be free when it is released ( People who bought the game before f2p release get cosmetic items
recommended: in-game crystals for costumes and some other premium gifts)\n\n-DD1 has cell-shade and simple graphics. DD2's graphics are resembling a good animation movie
hoursPlayed: it has cartoon/animation like graphic concept.\n\n-DD1 use mana as currency
voteText: DD 2 differentiate mana and currency. Now we have gold coins $$.\n\n-DD1 just have 1-2 basic costume per character and you need to buy DLCs for them. In DD2 we have evolving and much more detailed costumes ( even at this stage
helpfulPercent: there are many compared to DD1)
votesHelpful: which you can buy with real money currency.\n\n-DD1 has tons of DLCs
votesTotal: (it is not %100 clear but) developers thinking of earning money from cosmetic items like MOBA's and supporting the game with free expansions.\n\n-DD1 has offline private option. İn DD2
votesFunny: you need to be online even though you are playing solo.\n\nYes DD2 has core mechanics from the first installation; but it looks better on the surface
commentsCount:
it feels better when you play it and it is much more refined than most of the other Early Access' and DD1.

Let's get to pros and cons part:

+ Will be F2P!
+ Fantastic graphics and colour palette
+ Refined gameplay mechanics ( developers are trying to make it much more stable )
+ Developers that are listening to us.
+ Good animations and rigging
+ As a pre-alpha
column16: it has less bugs than a lot of open beta phase games.\n+ Fun to play
column17: get repetitive after some time but not boring.\n+ Except a few trolls
column18:
the community is awesome.
+ Constant updates and hotfixes.


- Minor graphical bugs
- Some balance issues between classes
- Pet system needs some work
- 4 towers per character constrain some tactical elements
- As of now
column19:
the content game has falls a little short.

I think i managed to summerize what you can expect from the game at this stage. Hope it helps :)


TL;DR
Game is solid
column20: but falls short on content. If you are not sure about buying this and haven't played the DD1 before
column21: I suggest you to wait for it to be released for free."

Just as I started playing I could notice the differences between the first game and this one some are bad and some are good

Bad

Good

-Easier to find lobbys
-The tavern is now different introduncing more merchants and other service

So that's my review some thing can be wrong since I only played so far in the game, and It can change since the game is on Early Acess.You can ignore the in-game currency(gems) since it is used to help the developers from the game.But thats what i think :)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I liked the first Dungeon Defenders a lot. It's one of the most played games on my Steam account. I've only played a little bit of the sequel so far, but man, I am struggling to find any enjoyment in it.

The structure is mind-boggling. The focus on online/social taverns, extremely limited quick match options with no server browser, having to load back into the tavern in between every map in the campaign? What are the developers thinking? Forcing everyone to be online all the time and giving us no control over who we match up with leads to every game being half full of afk players or max level characters who are wiping the floor with the low level maps for some reason.

At least when playing solo in a private game, I finally get to stop and look at the maps and use some strategy. But even then if I exit out of a map and try to do another one, I run into errors saying that I have made too many matchmaking attempts recently and to wait a few minutes. Can't even play the game alone. Thanks Trendy.

I cannot recommend this game at all in its current state. If a loot and stat-based tower defense/action game sounds appealing to you, I would highly suggest playing the first game instead.
