reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nDon't like the free to play aspect. I would have gladly paid $60 for a better experience. I recall annoucements that you would only be able to pay for asthetic items, nothing that would make the game easier. Well you have to pay to have more than 4 heroes and pay for more inventory. I personally am not dumping in the money pit. As far as content goes, only 4 heroes(which is understandable with early acess), but who knows if you would have to pay for some hero packs when those come out. Tower changes for each class which is refreshing. Not that i didn't like the old towers but something new like that is good. Maps are terrible. There is no challenge on a build. The enemy paths are so short that you could literally build anywhere and win. Armor does not show up on your hero, so you will buy costumes. Again, i would have gladly paid money for the game to have that capability and avoid a money pit. Costumes, as of right now, aren't that great. A couple of good ones for a couple heroes. Huntress costumes are garbage in my opinion. Amount of content is lacking and bugs are present. I wouldn't expect anything else from even a game that was just realeased let alone an early access. The deciding factor for me is this has been in alpha for over a year. Seems like progress is going to be very slow considering they were working on it before it was released for early access. But don't worry, the money pits are up and functional so you can dump some money in. It is free to play so it's not like you are going to regret the decision to download, but not worth the time for me.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Most polished Alpha game I've ever played, it should be a Beta in this state!Bare in mind, I didn't play the first game, so I don't know how it compares.

I love this game, and I can't wait to see more people play it. It's about to go free to play (as intended) on October 13th. This game, blends together tower defence, and an arpg together into one game. You can play as a monk, a squire, a huntress, and an apprentice. With the hero deck system, you can swap between 4 characters (or more, if you buy the slots). Each hero has 4 abilities and 4 different tower types, and each hero has it's own specializations. Each of them feel unique and fun to play. The graphics, the art styles, and the soundtrack are all amazing. The gameplay itself is also really great, and I have yet to see any gamebreaking bugs even in this early alpha stage.

Pros:
+ graphics
+ sound
+ gameplay
+ loot/pets!
+ classes/abilities
+ Really fun to stratagize with friends!
+ Steam integration
Cons:
- Needs more weapon styles especially for Apprentice
- Needs a better way to level 40 - 50 instead of grinding same map
- Could use more maps/gamemodes (which I'm sure will be added)
- Could possibly use an explanation for Hero Stats. (when I first started I had no idea what to focus on)
- No trading system or player market yet

If you buy it before the 13th, your money will help develop this awesome game, and you'll get premium currency and other goodies. If you wait til it goes f2p, well, try the game out! It's very addicting and tons of fun.
Thanks for reading! :)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I do find this a very enjoyable game but i'm not one to grind for nm4 gear, rather i farm more of the events and monthlies which are the only real fun thing at this time about this game.

There has been talk of adding some of the DD1 events/options in and i hope they do; more variety of play will help players and this game over all.

Okay Here goes;
They continue to polish this game and to read player feedback
(Unfortunetly they don't always listen to said feedback but i'm optimistic they will eventually)
The graphics and character changes are nice
(but the bugs and coding issues cause me to play this way lower so most of their efforts are blurrs and i just bypass it)
I love all the pet changes that have been made
(lots of nice pets but no options to aquire more space unless you pay real money.)
No banks at all is definetly a big con here; you have to carry everything on your character with no storage options just buy bags with real money and that has a cap.  Also only one inventory for all characters.
Their personal interface is buggy and doesn't run well with Steam at times; definetly needs work.

I am one of the first to mention their prices but with their newest event the Carnival i am pleased to say they finally put in reasonable prices for the carnival tickets (don't get me started on that $48 skin though!!)

I will say to new players, the community can be fickle but not inhospitable just be open to learning and listening.  If you come in and yell at builders for not letting you build instead of asking why, you're not going far trust me.
Ask questions, read the forums and be patient, people will answer and help you.  Please don't push off their advise just because you don't like it or understand it initally; there are always elitists in every game but not all are!

I say try this even with the bug issues, see for yourself if this is a game for you, i feel it has tons of potential and growth if Trendy takes it the right way.  Right now all we can do is wait and hope they do.
I also say try not to be too put off by prices; 99% are cosmetic, the only things that are not are the bags and hero slots.

I am recommending this game in hopes it improves and becomes what they tell us it will be.  If it was finished now, i'd say stay clear but its still growing so don't let the Early Access or the F2P turn you away!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It is an interesting game especially for those who are looking for something free to play. There are many maps we can choose from and four different classes to play.

I personally enjoyed playing it with friends but after the first 10 - 15 hours i got bored of it. The gameplay itself is quite grindish so this is a game that should not be played alone.

There is a feature at the login screen where it gives you the option to join a group related to the game and if you do that you should receive some gems which you can spend at the in game's store. I joined it but it didn't gave me any gems. I hope it gets fixed soon...

It's not a pay to win type of game! The only thing they have at the store are cosmetic items that don't really affect your gameplay!

I'll give it a 7/10.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Remember this is still in EARLY ACCESS people! I told myself I'd never pay again for early access and I stuck to my guns with that in regards to DD II. I'm glad I waited.

I will start by describing what I have played so far to give you a point of view to read my thoughts from. I've played the game about 14 hours and have beat every map on the campaign on the starting hardness setting. I have a decent strategy on how to beat every map with using just the Mage. Normal difficulty or hard requires you have multiple characters leveled up to do physical damage.  I am almost level 30 and found a few good pets so far. The pet system is interesting. I like how you can get the eggs and hatch them but.... we are talking about RNG and the frustrations that come with it. I am always excited to see what the eggs turn into. So far the pets have been mostly crap. I did however get one legendary one and a few rares all of which do not have the stats I wish to have on them :( Don't think of pets as something which will make or break your character. It helps, but isn't going to determine your win/failure on a map.

Where are all the dang maps???? DD II has maybe 15 maps total as of 11/26/2015. Yes you can play the maps in different modes, wooo still the same dang maps. DD I had a ton of maps with the DLCs which were great and allowed for some interesting trap/field combinations.  DD II feels simplier, the only level which I feel has any difficulity to it is the Wyrvern Nest with Betsy on Easy. That was the first map I lost on during the campaign.  Above Easy hardness you need multiple characters or happen to play with someone who has a physical damage tower based hero.

Pros:
+Free to Play: Awesome! Does it include free cake?
+Tower Defense: Yes please, give me more!
+Variety of Critters: a good amount and variety of monsters.
+Evolving Pets: Who doesn't want to catch em all?
+Tons of Loot!: You can find what you are looking for stat-wise fairly easily.
+Getting loot 99% of the time for the character you are playing on: yes! thank you jeebus. It frustrated me to no end playing on X character in DD I and getting amazing items for other heros but not the hero I'm currently playing.

Neutral:
+/- Micro transactions: The amount of stuff you can spend premium currency on is a bit rediculous. Want to ensure the egg you are hatching evolves a certain way? Spend premium currency. Want cosmetics? Spend currency. Its not game-breaking, just let it be known you have many ways to spend premium currency.
+/- Simplier: No leveling up 6 characters to utilize one or two things from a Monk and Knight and Mage while you are playing on X character for Y reason.

Cons:
- Tons of Loot!: There is so much crap that drops it takes a good 5+ minutes to sort through it all after heading back.
- I feel meh" about it. Sure it kills time and takes strategy
date:
but I could also not play it for 2 months and be completely fine with that. Its like I'm watching a movie I've seen a hundred times before. Sure its a good movie but... where is the innovation?
- Having to pay for expanded bag space: I feel like you guys decided to throw so much loot at people to just make the upgraded bag slots valid purchase to people because its F-T-P and its their way to show patronage and support while getting something ingame.

Remember this is still ALPHA/Early Access. I am not giving up on this game yet. I really hope the Devs have some shake-N-bake up their robes to bring the current game up to the expectations people have for the game. Maybe my expectations are set too high for DD II
recommended: maybe not. Is it worth downloading? Its alright and kills time
hoursPlayed: the only reason I played as much as I did is because I've had an enjoyable experience so far and do not like losing. Download those 7 gigs and give the game a try
voteText: but don't make your final decision on the game till its actually fully released."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I played 800+ hours at DD1 and as Trendy totally gave up on it (no bug fixes, no new maps), I was super excited to hear there was a DD2. But after being release (in early access, which is still the case now) the reviews were pretty mixed, especially from the ones that players DD1. So I waited a few months hoping the game will use the same magic recipe as DD1 and will be an improvement.

As the game was on sale, I decided to get it and give it a try hoping I will have a tremendous number of hours coming on. Unfortunately after 20 hours on it I was pretty disappointed and don't understand why Trendy made so many bad changes:

PRO:
- better graphics
- details on monsters for the incoming wave
- can see your defenses range by holding the Shift key.
and to be honest that's pretty much it.

CONS:
- right after getting the game I wasn't able to join any public game, the servers weren't working properly. Seems to have gone better but it seems like that's a recurring issue. Even joining the public tavern sometimes doesn't work.
- 4 heroes with 4 towers, compared to 8 x 5. They might add some more later on but right now we are missing a lot on diversity.
- the stats system has totally changed and is so confusing: gear rating/comparison doesn't seem right, can't boost particular stats anymore (you've to find objects with stats you want), we've lost the range stats (no more high-range harpons).
- this game will become a free to play (Yeah!) but some upgrades will require real money (Boooo!)
- most of the shortcuts have changed from DD1
- DD1 was having a listing of all games and it was easy to join the party you felt will be fun to play (map/mode/difficulty). Now you just join a public tavern and have to select a map+difficulty and you might join a starting game or it will create a new game (and if you quit/cancel right away you are loosing social points, wth!?)

So far I haven't had any fun playing DD2, I might try to continue leveling up (I've 3 heroes lvl 20) to see if it gets better and unlock some other maps but I'm seriously considering going back to DD1...

I want to like this game, but without knowing what the game's content is about, I can't. The main issue I had was performance issues, not the usual kind of fps issues that people are complaining about on the forums, but there was few troubles just trying to get the game launched.

On my first try, I clicked the Play button in the launcher, then nothing happened. When I sorted programs by RAM usage in the Task Manager, I found out that the .exe was the the bottom of the list, so I had to force close it.
My second try got a step further, which got me relieved. However, the DD2 logo appeared, then the whole thing froze. Appeared as Not Responding" RAM usage doesn't cost as much as running Steam.
I decided to give myself a final try. Sadly the result I got was the same.You might say:
The game's in closed alpha - give the developers some time. Um

God willing we'll all meet again in Spaceballs 2: The Search for more Money."

What do you do when you've milked every possible cent out of your game via DLC
hoursPlayed: and indie bundles?  You make a 'sequel' with less depth to draw in the F2P crowd.\n\nThere isn't much to say about Dungeon Defenders 2.  It's practically the same game with less towers
voteText: smaller maps
helpfulPercent: fewer bosses
votesHelpful: fewer heroes
votesTotal:
and an even more tedious grind-to-progress system.  And while the first game could have stood to benefit from more focus this shifts the focus more towards hero action than a tower defense game.  Dropping in a multiplayer game you will rarely be able to build your own fortifications as you start with little mana and the players already there will have taken up the defense limit.  It forces you to recruit friends to play so you can manage some strategy or treat the game as if it were a shallow Diablo-clone focusing on your hero stats.

Technically the game is in rough shape.  After nearly a year of Early Access on Steam (and a longer period where it wasn't available for sale) optimization is extremely poor.  Stutters and slowdowns are constant on my 770 with an i5 processor and in two days I've lost count of the number of times I've had to Alt F4 out of a loading screen that hangs forever.

Updated: The loading screen issues have been fixed although there is still a degree of stuttering after transitions.

To their credit there's no P2W going on.  The stuff you buy with cash is mostly cosmetic and/or speeding up the time you can acquire pets and such.  And

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nFor all you who are fans of the origional dungeon defenders or dungeon defenders eternity, this game with be a rollercoaster of nostalgia and wft? For those of you who havent played the previous said games, this will be a fun, quirky, 3rd person shooter, tower defence that can entertain you for hours. If you do not know, DD2 is a tower defence based on the fact that you must defend your base by using towers from 1 of 4 classes. Each class can place down a vastly differnt set of towers from each other, and so it is highly suggested that you play with other people of different classes (so sorry all of you fellow defenders who would play as the squire and solo every map). Other than placing towers, you are supposed to use your third person shooter skills, that you obviously aquired from Star Wars Battle Front 2, to shoot the enemies and help defend your base. Overall, the main point i want to portray is that DD2 is BALANCED. The towers of every class are really good and helpful (yes, the huntress's traps are REALLY good!), and each class has different attacks and abillities to make every class able to dish out decent damage without the use of towers.

At the moment trendy focuses on providing more skins (10€ / skin) which seems to be a greater idea than fixing bugs ( like Ogres who are stuck in the spawn ) or providing content which makes the game worth playing.

Sadly i can not recommend this game anymore since the major focus is on making money.

Feeling punished and betrayed for beeing a long term player. If i could i would refund my collectors edition.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I want to like this game I do, but for the reasons I liked DD1, I just can't like the game. I know this game is not DD1, but its just missing the aspect of the game that made me love DD1.

Everything is now about item drops. I mean why even have levels anymore? In DD1, from the moment you entered the game with a new character, you assinged your first skill point, that character became yours.  In DD2, originally I had to get level 5, to assing spec points. Now they removed that feature, and replaced it with skill sphere. Oh joy another thing that become completely dependant on item drops. Waiting on item drops is what completely bogged down End Game DD1.  Now its all about finding the best items. I just can't get into this game at all.

I do like some of the changes, especially to the Hero skills... but overall, its just lost the very thing that I loved about it. Leveling my own character, and creating my own build.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I played 800+ hours at DD1 and as Trendy totally gave up on it (no bug fixes, no new maps), I was super excited to hear there was a DD2. But after being release (in early access, which is still the case now) the reviews were pretty mixed, especially from the ones that players DD1. So I waited a few months hoping the game will use the same magic recipe as DD1 and will be an improvement.

As the game was on sale, I decided to get it and give it a try hoping I will have a tremendous number of hours coming on. Unfortunately after 20 hours on it I was pretty disappointed and don't understand why Trendy made so many bad changes:

PRO:
- better graphics
- details on monsters for the incoming wave
- can see your defenses range by holding the Shift key.
and to be honest that's pretty much it.

CONS:
- right after getting the game I wasn't able to join any public game, the servers weren't working properly. Seems to have gone better but it seems like that's a recurring issue. Even joining the public tavern sometimes doesn't work.
- 4 heroes with 4 towers, compared to 8 x 5. They might add some more later on but right now we are missing a lot on diversity.
- the stats system has totally changed and is so confusing: gear rating/comparison doesn't seem right, can't boost particular stats anymore (you've to find objects with stats you want), we've lost the range stats (no more high-range harpons).
- this game will become a free to play (Yeah!) but some upgrades will require real money (Boooo!)
- most of the shortcuts have changed from DD1
- DD1 was having a listing of all games and it was easy to join the party you felt will be fun to play (map/mode/difficulty). Now you just join a public tavern and have to select a map+difficulty and you might join a starting game or it will create a new game (and if you quit/cancel right away you are loosing social points, wth!?)

So far I haven't had any fun playing DD2, I might try to continue leveling up (I've 3 heroes lvl 20) to see if it gets better and unlock some other maps but I'm seriously considering going back to DD1...

I want to like this game, but without knowing what the game's content is about, I can't. The main issue I had was performance issues, not the usual kind of fps issues that people are complaining about on the forums, but there was few troubles just trying to get the game launched.

On my first try, I clicked the Play button in the launcher, then nothing happened. When I sorted programs by RAM usage in the Task Manager, I found out that the .exe was the the bottom of the list, so I had to force close it.
My second try got a step further, which got me relieved. However, the DD2 logo appeared, then the whole thing froze. Appeared as Not Responding" RAM usage doesn't cost as much as running Steam.
I decided to give myself a final try. Sadly the result I got was the same.You might say:
The game's in closed alpha - give the developers some time. Um

Early Access Review

I have never played DD1 or DDE. After playing DD2, i really like the game as it has all or not most of my favourite gaming genres, TD, 3rd person shooter/hack and slash. This game is really fun if u have a group of friends that can coordinate well together. But i have played this game most of the time with strangers and i can say that 90% of the time i meet friendly people. So, i can say that the community is good here. The devs have come up with new content for the future and bugfixes here and there.

So... great game,good community,good devs = GET THE GAME!

Also, there will obviously be bugs in early access, u can't expect it to be running smoothly without bugs. But so far the bugs i have experienced isn't game breaking.

Thanks for reading my review. Hope to see you in-game! :D

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Game Review
The game, as directed from the title is a dungeon based defence game in which the player builds towers in order to stop enemy minions from destroying the main base. As well as the main objective on the harder maps, are side objectives which the player needs to defend otherwise it will allow for more enemies, often flying types to be able to access the map making it harder especially without certain classes.
Logical thinking is required by the player to complete for ever changes and more difficult maps. As the game calls upon the player to think through the use of their 'Tower Budget' whilst building defences to stop the enemy minions form reaching the main base, the better the tower the higher the cost. Along with the budget, the player has the choice of class types, which impacts the levels massively, as depending on what characters are on the team during the missions effects the difficulty as some cannot attack air units or some are not able to take as many hits as others.
Along with the thinking required is the effect of the choices made, as in the game they are able to have a very negative or positive outcome as for example having a Mage try to tank hits from enemies would be a poor choice compared to having a knight tank the hits. But there is a lot more than just deciding what person defends where, each player chooses their class each one having different abilities or attributes that can help the team and as stated above the choice of towers will be one to rule all or end all within an instant.
Considering these whilst looking at the game play allows you to see that things are coming together well, the game entices the player into what is called a 'one more round' mood, in which if a player is enjoying the game by winning or by having or rethink the same map several times to pass. As well as being able to invite friends to have a more cooperative team and a more thrilling experience as everyone will be able to have a laugh no matter what the outcome.
Overall my experience with Dungeon Defenders 2 was a good experience and produced a lot of good points, however with every game there are a few things that can be tweaked. Such as the enchantment system as I never truly understood it whilst using it and the glitch at the main hub (tavern) where players fall through the floor.

Overall i give DD2 a 9/10 rating.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First of all i have to say you've done an amazing job at making the sequel to dungeon defender, its everything i hope it to be and more. Firstly lets go over the game play, dungeon defenders two is a 3D tower defense game basally but more vamped up than you typical td game. You play as one of 4 characters that is available at the moment due to the game being in pre alpha, which is the apprentice, monk, huntress and squire. The apprentice a ranged fighter and is useful for placing down extremely high dps towers that deal aoe dmg but is quite squishy and has low base dmg. The huntress is a high dmg sniper with medium dmg traps they can place down, useful for taking out flying monsters. the squire is a tank with towers that deal a medium to high single target dmg, but makes up for the single target problem by tanking while his towers takes down mobs. Lastly is the monk, who is a melee fighter who deals aoe dmg and also has medium dmg aoe towers but he has extremely hard times dealing with flying enemies.

The game play that is available at the moment is both challenging and fun at the same time, along with that all maps are beatable with the right strategy which is necessary to have in more higher level maps. The strategy element in the game has been quite nice at the moment,  to be able to win any map you need to use a certain amount of strategy by coordinating with your team mates, for example having the tank take multiple lanes and drawing agro while the towers kill off the enemies. This level of strategy in placed is at a good balance where you can easily pick up how to play properly and the learning curve is quite gentle to newer players to jump right in and not feel way out classed.

The texture of the game is quite nice with no eye sore images where its to bright or to dark, and doesn't require a high end computer to run the game at a nice medium quality. so far the game has no bugs to be found and from my experience has a smooth game play experience and is really enjoyable to relax with.

overall the only aspect of the game which annoys me is the enchanting system in place, it clunky and slow as well as costing way to much gold to the ratio that you earn per level you win. in my opinion i would make an option to fast enchant the item you're trying to upgrade along with reducing the cost of enchanting slightly or increase the gold income per round or income for selling items

Other than that i would highly recommend the game to all players that are into this type of game.
Rating 9/10

I really only have one issue, but it's a huge one. First let me preface this by stating that my ISP is absolutely terrible, so my internet is only decent in a small window shortly after midnight. Even when I'm alone, in a private session, the game is laggy and unplayable.

If you have a good, reliable internet connection and enjoy tower defense games, then give it a try. If your internet sucks, it's not worth the hassle.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I loved the first game... Not at first, though. In fact, when I first saw all the DLC, I thought Dungeon Defenders was a horrid cash grab. I only got into it because I was cooerced by my friends...

And I'm glad they did.

Dungeon Defenders was a true pleasure to play, and nice breath of fresh air in a genre I never even considered. Since then, I have played Sanctum (1 and 2), Orcs Must Die 2, but neither really cured the itch the first left behind.

Then I played this... and I didn't really stop until my friend and I crushed the main campaign.

Dungeon Defenders 2 is a true successor to a truly wonderful game, which even runs beautiful on my PoS laptop. The gameplay feels faster, the loot plentiful to the point of slowing you down a moment in the menus to see and sell --which works in the game's favor; it has you stop, take a breather in between missions for each one to really feel unique and not just more fodder for the slaughter.

The game is nowhere near perfect, but there's no denying a lot of love went into this... and it's F2P, so there's no harm in trying it. Don't take my word, don't take anybody's; if you have a toaster, try it out. Worst case is you are sucked into the game for hours, and left wondering why you haven't put any pants on yet.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Deep review This is a towerdefense game of a 3rd person view. I would say this game can be comapred to diablo series. Because of the loot system and the grinding involved into it. So lets start of picking your 4 heroes, each hero has its own kit/style.

Mage
The mage has a  LOT  of aoe spells and places turrets that also deal aoe dmg. Hes ranged and builds turrets pretty well (The mage has a freeze turret that helps pretty well in defense also because his normal turrets deal aoe dmg he can easy deal a lot more dmg). The weapon he uses i a staff.

Fighter
The fighter is a mele class hero and uses of course a sword. He can build small walls better than others (they deal dmg when someone tries to destroy them).

Hunter
The hunter places traps that can CC (Crow Control: Stuns, Slows, Silence etc). Also some just deal dmg. She places turrets that can poision the target for a small amout of time. She is ranged and uses a bow.

Monk
I like to call him lee sin  Because in league of legends lee sin is a blind monk  . Hes weapon is a staff but different from the mages cuz he is mele. He can create totems that will heal you or buff your turrets.

Gameplay As i said this is a towerdefense game with where you can roam freely building your towers and walls to not let the enemies get pass you and break the core. You have crystals (green crystals is like your building material and blue is more like your mana to let you use spells). There is a limit on how much building you can build in the field so if a person uses all that liming to build only in one lane and dosent want to destroy it youre screwd.
The  loot  system is almost the same as diablo (if not the same). A big amount of grinding is nessecay for leveling up and getting the best loot. Most of the loot you get are usefull at start but at the end game lvl 38 for example, 95% of the loot you get will be useless and is just junk that you sell. Even if you get a legendary it might be useless, someway because of the level cuz youre grinding on low levels and somethimes just of its stats.
So lets talk about  XP . At the start its easy to level up as you proceed the campain but after youre done it will get easier. To unlock the insane difficulty and nightmare, nightmare 2 and so on. You have to complete the called quests, but the quest are no more than just lvl up to 50 so when youre lvl for example 38, you have to replay ALOT of the same level to get the most xp out of it and do it agan and again and again till you reach lvl 50 and unlock the insane difficulty to get better loot. Here is where i think is a big gap and alot of people thinking of quiting when they reach this certain point.
You can see that the developmers has helped a bit and added daily exp to the first finishing missions. But on the other hand there is still something missing. That gap from lvl (exmpl) 38 to lvl 50 takes a lot of time of replayability so i think that the devolopers can add something into that like for exaple letting them acces the unlimited modes at a lower level than at 40 and still keeping the insane difficulty there. I think that would at least do something (if not fix it).
Co-Op  is in this game and i highly recommend playing this game with a friend. You can still solo it and do well. But plaing multiplayer is easier because heroes in this game has a great synergy with each others for example lee sin (Monk class) can create totems that gives your turret a lot of power and a significantly increase in dmg.

Free2Pay As the develpers are saying its NOT a pay2win game. Right now you can only use special money on cosmetics and chests that you find as loot. The chest CAN have very good loot but often dosent and just gives you a small boost on your items (Other words: you get better loot but not too far away from what you had). I hope this systems will stay as the realise comes.

Development The game patches is pretty common and i mean it. There was a patch yesterday and a patch today. Those patches arent that big BUT add small features that the community requested. For example the sort panel on bags that wasent before todays patch. You can see (or read) with your own eyes that the developers react to their community and helps.

Final verdict I dont mind grinding and farming for loot like in diablo with a small gap between the hero lvl. Graphics are ok for a free to play game and port is well optimised. This game is specialy good to play with friends but you can still solo it. The developers are nice and  hear  the community.

I give this game a  8/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

You know, for a game that's going to be free, this game is absolutely amazing. I havent beaten the campaign yet but it feels pretty easy so far, though each level I go through gets more complex than the last. So far the monk was mind numbing to play but the mage was an absolute blast. I dont really feel like writing a long drawn out review at the time so I'll just list out some pointers.

+ Items can have cool enchantments like 10% chance to shock your attacker for X damage" or "-1  second manabomb cooldown" which means you're not always just going to be looking for which weapon hits hardest or gives the most of x stat.

+ Co-op with friends is easy to set up and play together. Being 7 levels behind because I wanted to try a different class at the start didnt make us have to go back and level me up. It was still possible to beat the level we left off on.

- This is probably more of a personal point but the monk feels really bland to me. I thought the game was a little bit of a let down when I'd picked him first. But I didnt like him in the other games either.

+ From what I can tell there's alot of customization to be done through Skill orbs such as bonus crit chance
date: specific bonuses to towers (such as the ice tower slowing more

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's DD1 with upgraded visuals. Very enjoyable. For a while.

It lacks all the little things, the depth, that makes you want to keep playing the game beyond the first 10-15 hours.

In DD1, you could really delve into stats, builds, and have fun with varied maps and challenges. Plus, there was an actual feel of progression. Here, you grind through a lvl 30 map until you get to the level cap (50), simply because it's better than any other gamemode or map when it comes to XP per hour per effort.

In truth, if DD2 didn't kill all activity on DD1, I'd still be playing DD1.

This game is not an improvement. It's a dumbed down game with better graphics.
But the potentional is there.

Even as a pre alpha game the gameplay is pretty darn good especially if you include the fact that the UI is more user friendly and also the POV is much much better than DD1. Not only that but the graphics aree really good compared to DD1 whose models and textures were pretty dark and didn't seem that much satisfying to play with. Overall the game is somewhat buggy as sometimes you might experience some usual pre alpha stuff you find in most games. The multiplayer is ok but laggy at some times. reviewText:
Early Access Review

Approx. 65 hours in:

I've never really been much for making reviews, but I guess I could say I would gladly recommend this, would even pay 10-20 euro for the game at it's current stage or better.

I do like that they decided to make the game F2P, with microtransactions for costumes, that would never affect gameplay (many people are upset, and I don't see why since it only changes your appearance, but fair enough).

Many seems to complain about having to buy extra inventory space, and why? I've reached level 50 on all 4 characters, sure I've grinded a little bit, but with the monthly mission, and daily missions, all different characters, lots of different maps, I'd say I haven't grown bored yet from always having variety of a certain kind. Sure, the characters are each amazing for one specific build and suck at the rest, but does it matter? It does come into play with tactics when you reach the end, because the dropped gear is most likely useless if you want defense gear for a tower builder, and you're playing on your hero character, since the passives" will be made for that particular character you play as. That adds challenge

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So, I've written two other reviews, and I'm coming back to write a 3rd. What can I say? I bought the first Dungeon Defenders on my Playstation 3, loved it, so I purchased it on my pc with all of the DLC. One of my all time favorite games, this one had a lot to live up to. So does it? Heck yeah it does! I purchased the game on Early Access, and let me just say that this is Early Access done right! With so many dev teams abusing the Early Access platform on steam, this definetly gives me hope for Early Access in general. The developers respond to feedback and even allow players to vote for changes to the game on the launcher. Early Adopters were rewarded with $30 of in-game currency as well as a unique cosmetic for each of the 4 heroes currently available in the game (although I do wish the items were a little flashier for bragging purposes :D) I would say the campaign is a bit shorter than the original, and develops the story very little. I would assume that expansions are on their way, as I cannot stress enough how little the plot progresses, so if you're looking for a full story, you won't find it yet.

But how's the gameplay? The tower defense is amazing, although there are many tower's that haven't returned or have been altered significantly. But to make up for this, there are a few new towers. Hero spells have also been changed, and a whole new type of energy is used for them, which frees you up. You don't have to choose between using hero abilities, or getting that tower upgrade you desperately need. The action element of the game definetly feels nice, but you won't find yourself being able to completely ditch towers like you could with a maxed barb or huntress in the first Dungeon Defenders. You could argue that this is actually a plus though.

Should you buy it? F2P? YES! What are you waiting for!? P2P? YES! The Devs deserve the support! But I recommend trying it F2P first, just to make sure it's your thing.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's Dungeon Defenders I, but it's F2P!

This is good and bad, though. It's good because, you know, it's free, but it's bad because they have microtransactions and DLC to make the game generate income.
In my opinion, this doesn't matter too much, as all of the items you pay for are purely cosmetic and give no special advantage in any way.

It also has better graphics than the first game, quests, daily missions, a better upgrading system, another way to upgrade your character, a better tavern, and more!

And it's still in alpha.

I'd rate this game 9.5/10. It still needs some more maps, but again, it's in alpha. It also needs PVP!

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nIf you like RPG's and tower defence games, this is the game for you. Choose between an apprentice, huntress, monk or squire to defend Etheria from the Old ones. They're trying to take the magical crystal back with waves and waves of orcs, goblins and all manner of crazy beasts. Level up and fully custimize your hero with stat points, spehres, pets and gear to deal with the baddies in the way you see fit. Work on your hero themselves or your defences. Each hero has there own set of defences such as walls and towers and traps to ''defend'' the chosen objective. Each mission is very colorful and completed with difficulties for your team to overcome. A great co -op and friends game , becuase you all need to work together, hero and defence wise to protect the objective and well, from experiece if you don't....you fail. You spend equal time defending, as setting up defences to gearing up and looking through loot. It's also not a play to win, they only negative is a long loading time or game crashes but i'm sure Itll be fixed and renderd ASAP...

date:
i'll have to change my review.

I liked this game a lot -  it was hard but you got rewarded with good gear so this kept you going.
Trendy kept nerfing the maps to make it easier for casual players and now they have added better loot so people dont have to grind so much.

Sounds great
recommended:
but it isnt.

Getting a good item feels more like a freebie than a reward right now and with each map they have added like the "Spooky maps" or the latest "Harbinder map" they simply do not care about the End Game Players cause the loot isn't as good as it is on the regular maps. So why even do it ? You probably do it one time then let it go.

Later they added a Nightmare 4 version of the "Spooky maps" but the loot was and is still useless ... good job!

At the moment trendy focuses on providing more skins (10€ / skin) which seems to be a greater idea than fixing bugs ( like Ogres who are stuck in the spawn ) or providing content which makes the game worth playing.

The latest patch also nerfed all the gear we were farming for more than 300h but there was at least one good thing
hoursPlayed:
they finally realized that they should remove the legacy gear which gave some people a very big advantage over other people who didn't have a chance to get it.

Sadly i can not recommend this game anymore since the major focus is on making money.

Overall opinion:

Feeling punished and betrayed for beeing a long term player. If i could i would refund my collectors edition.

I played some 500+ hours in DD1, and while that isn't a ton of time, I'd like to think that I am a fan of the games. I've only played upwards of 25 hours in DD2 and to be honest, I couldn't be more pleased so far. That said, judging this game now would be ridiculous, it's in PRE-ALPHA, which translate to this not finished game, they will add more things and the game will continue to improve. So just wait a bit, taking a pre-alpha game at face value would be silly. So a word of advice from a random gamer, if you're on the fence about this game wait until it's released to give it a chance.

Pros of the game:
-Great graphics
-More levels
-New enemy types/ bosses

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I played 800+ hours at DD1 and as Trendy totally gave up on it (no bug fixes, no new maps), I was super excited to hear there was a DD2. But after being release (in early access, which is still the case now) the reviews were pretty mixed, especially from the ones that players DD1. So I waited a few months hoping the game will use the same magic recipe as DD1 and will be an improvement.

As the game was on sale, I decided to get it and give it a try hoping I will have a tremendous number of hours coming on. Unfortunately after 20 hours on it I was pretty disappointed and don't understand why Trendy made so many bad changes:

PRO:
- better graphics
- details on monsters for the incoming wave
- can see your defenses range by holding the Shift key.
and to be honest that's pretty much it.

CONS:
- right after getting the game I wasn't able to join any public game, the servers weren't working properly. Seems to have gone better but it seems like that's a recurring issue. Even joining the public tavern sometimes doesn't work.
- 4 heroes with 4 towers, compared to 8 x 5. They might add some more later on but right now we are missing a lot on diversity.
- the stats system has totally changed and is so confusing: gear rating/comparison doesn't seem right, can't boost particular stats anymore (you've to find objects with stats you want), we've lost the range stats (no more high-range harpons).
- this game will become a free to play (Yeah!) but some upgrades will require real money (Boooo!)
- most of the shortcuts have changed from DD1
- DD1 was having a listing of all games and it was easy to join the party you felt will be fun to play (map/mode/difficulty). Now you just join a public tavern and have to select a map+difficulty and you might join a starting game or it will create a new game (and if you quit/cancel right away you are loosing social points, wth!?)

So far I haven't had any fun playing DD2, I might try to continue leveling up (I've 3 heroes lvl 20) to see if it gets better and unlock some other maps but I'm seriously considering going back to DD1...

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I want to like this game, but without knowing what the game's content is about, I can't. The main issue I had was performance issues, not the usual kind of fps issues that people are complaining about on the forums, but there was few troubles just trying to get the game launched.

On my first try, I clicked the Play button in the launcher, then nothing happened. When I sorted programs by RAM usage in the Task Manager, I found out that the .exe was the the bottom of the list, so I had to force close it.
My second try got a step further, which got me relieved. However, the DD2 logo appeared, then the whole thing froze. Appeared as Not Responding" RAM usage doesn't cost as much as running Steam.
I decided to give myself a final try. Sadly the result I got was the same.You might say:
The game's in closed alpha - give the developers some time. Um

reviewText:
Early Access Review

God willing we'll all meet again in Spaceballs 2: The Search for more Money."

What do you do when you've milked every possible cent out of your game via DLC
hoursPlayed: and indie bundles?  You make a 'sequel' with less depth to draw in the F2P crowd.\n\nThere isn't much to say about Dungeon Defenders 2.  It's practically the same game with less towers
voteText: smaller maps
helpfulPercent: fewer bosses
votesHelpful: fewer heroes
votesTotal:
and an even more tedious grind-to-progress system.  And while the first game could have stood to benefit from more focus this shifts the focus more towards hero action than a tower defense game.  Dropping in a multiplayer game you will rarely be able to build your own fortifications as you start with little mana and the players already there will have taken up the defense limit.  It forces you to recruit friends to play so you can manage some strategy or treat the game as if it were a shallow Diablo-clone focusing on your hero stats.

Technically the game is in rough shape.  After nearly a year of Early Access on Steam (and a longer period where it wasn't available for sale) optimization is extremely poor.  Stutters and slowdowns are constant on my 770 with an i5 processor and in two days I've lost count of the number of times I've had to Alt F4 out of a loading screen that hangs forever.

Updated: The loading screen issues have been fixed although there is still a degree of stuttering after transitions.

To their credit there's no P2W going on.  The stuff you buy with cash is mostly cosmetic and/or speeding up the time you can acquire pets and such.  And
votesFunny: of course
commentsCount: there's daily quests
column16: gold farming
column17: all that 'fun' stuff.  All Trendy has done  here is repackage DD1 and wrapped it up into a nuBlizzard F2P shell."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Hard to review this one, as a fan of the original. Where to begin? Well...let's start off with what I don't like.

The game is quite a bit easier. The maps are visually more interesting to look at and have more full 3D depth to them, which makes them interesting to run around in at times. But each lane is identified for you immediately, and the maps are designed in such a way that you can't have an aha!" moment as you discover a way to place a single tower to cover multiple choke-points. Either the developer placed the chokepoint for you and pointed you right to it
date: or the chokepoint doesn't exist. This can help to eliminate the feeling of "trial and error" gameplay that existed in the first game
recommended: but it also means you can never feel like you're outsmarting the developer when you find a good way to place your towers.\n\nIn some ways
hoursPlayed: this doesn't necessarily change the final feeling of the game
voteText: as in the first one
helpfulPercent: once you figured it out
votesHelpful: you always placed towers in the best spots. I suppose this makes it easier to play the game in public groups or with friends that don't really play video games the same way you do
votesTotal: but it makes all of the maps feel a little samey after awhile
votesFunny: because you never get to experience that first moment of wonder as you treat the map like a puzzle to be solved.\n\nThe pricing of the cosmetic items is...quite high. I find myself learning to enjoy the default skins
commentsCount: since purchasing the outfits i'd like would quickly put this game at a higher price than an off the shelf
column16: AAA title. I don't have a problem with the microtransactions themselves
column17:
I think it'd just be nicer if they were a little more "micro" so I could get a few skins and not feel like i'm getting robbed.

Now on to what's been improved!

The new hero-deck system will (eventually) prevent a single player from effectively filling every role. Playing with friends in the first game could be quite difficult at times
column18: because you were capable of leveling up and gearing out the entire cast
column19: and placing every tower type. Your friends could quickly outgrow you
column20: and if you didn't play a ranger or barbarian
column21: there was little reason for you to be in the game with such a person
column22: since their towers would be better than what you could make. Being limited to a certain number of heroes encourages you to work together - once there are more hero types than there are deck slots
column23: you'll need at least two players to do everything. It's forced co-op sure
column24: but at least you can always be useful to your friends
column25: since you can bring something that they cannot.\n\nThe way they introduce new unit types as mini-bosses feels good. Later maps and harder difficulties can repeatedly spawn mini-boss versions of these enemies too. Since there are a lot of things that can define an enemy (such as movement speed
column27: special attacks
column29: they keep your defenses in check and ensure that everyone has something to contribute. Defenses and your attentiveness get tested as each lane fights to divert your attention across the map. The new
column30: proper bosses feel a lot more interesting than all of the bosses from the first game
column31: too. They have mechanics that make them more than a "bullet sponge"
column32: and it was an excellent move making them a bit of an outside force that interacts with the map and the waves in interesting ways
column33:
instead of just being placed awkwardly and requiring that you blindly hit it with regular attacks and awkwardly placed towers.

The aesthetics of the game are sweet. Everything is much nicer to look at.

I think my biggest complaint is that I just wish the game was harder. Not in a "just make the numbers bigger" way
column34: but that the maps were actually more interesting to play. It feels like the entire campaign is a tutorial to get you acclimated to the games mechanics. The maps never seem to get nearly as complex or interesting as they were in the first game....The revisited maps in 'the harbinger awakens' content update come closer and are definitely more fun than the maps that came before it
column35: which gives me hope for the future. You really can't go wrong with "free" though
column36: and I can see myself losing a few more evenings as I continue to play this with my fiancée. But ultimately
column37: I don't think either of us will be sinking dozens or even hundreds of hours into it like we did the first time around."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

**Disclaimer: this preview is coming from my perspective with +500 hrs in game.
**tl;dr is at bottom

-First thing to say is this game has massive contents, tons of maps, epic boss fights given the fact that it's an Alpha game.
-The community is friendly and supportive (generally) if you're having a hard time looking rooms with people, trying changing to EU servers ( use Discord apps or forum, plenty of folks are in need of company too!)
-The art of the game is charming and colorful much like its strategy aspect. Combinations of traps and defenses is the hidden gems of this game ( like Water trap goes really well with Electric aura, Frost turrets and heroes's skills, .. etc)
-The possibility of defense layout is endless, but due to some unbalanced perks of a certain traps, the current layout is pretty much plain and similar. However, there's a undescribable joy when you and your friends discovered a new layout that actually work.
-The diversity in each heroes is wonderfully rich. Each and every characters have their own fun and perks so think twice before you choose your heroes.
-The only one thing that can really bore you is the grind. Much like every games, you must farm to be stronger, to be able to climb higher; but this game is weighted heavily on the farm and the endless grind, which is fun at first but will quickly turn into a chore rather than a game. So my advice is to not focusing too much on your stats. Looking for a piece of gear that has 1% higher in passives won't bring you any good, only frustuating and miserable; just enjoy the victory with your comrades after an epic match.

> To DD1 players, this game is designed with the co-op in mind, so it's probably a lot harder to solo; try to find some friends to play with.

**tl;dr: A good co-op strategy tower defense with a mix of RPG, game requires you to be quick on your feet, not just afk and let the defenses do all the jobs. Despite the name it's completely different from DD1 so don't compare it too much with its former self.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI played the OG Dungeon Defenders since launch and I put well over 1500 hours into over the years and DD2 does not disappoint. It is extremely addicting and easy to get into. Most tower defense games you just place stuff and go afk for a few min but DD2 makes it incredibly interactive and almost like a tower defense mmorpg. Characters have attacks that feel pretty satisfying. It can work with any playstyle. If you just want to take it easy or cause yourself many hours of frustration, this game will suit your needs. I do recommend playing on easy or normal until you get a good feel for where to place towers. The classes are all very fun and new classes will probably continue to be added. This is the best game to screw around with friends and see how much you can push yourselves.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nDungeon Defenders II is a tower defense game. It has a lot of features like items, different characters, leveling system both for characters and items, pet system, and so on. There are premium contents too like extra character slots, costumes, etc. You can play with four players at a time, and you can combine your skills to get the best setup for the map and defeat the enemies. Also, there are monthly and daily missions for rewards like pet eggs, money or items. Sometimes these missions undoable because you don't have that character or you don't have enough item power. The only disadvantage is that the game is still in development, so there are little bugs, and there are lots of updates. You can have a really good time and if you have some money I recommend you to buy extra character slots so you can easily solo almost every maps/level.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Dungeon Defenders 2 is more or less the same as it's predecessor. Although there are less characters, less maps, and less viable strategies. The only thing really new in this game is Microtransactions. Community is rude, unlwelcoming and elitism is as rampant as it was in the first game. Leveling is slow, boring and ultimately devolves into pointless loot grind. The game is also very buggy and crash prone, requiring a lot of work to get to it run in a stable state.

DD2 feels like a hollow shell of what the Dungeon Defenders was. None of the charm of the original game is present. Time will tell if DD2 improves, but right now I'm not holding out any hope.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Having over 400 + hours invested in DD1 i was excited to know that DD2 was on early release. rushed to buy for me and my brother who are avid fans, only for our dreams to be crushed by a gutted and completely different game.

Towers - Seem to all be made out of the thinest wet toliet paper one can find, along with having the range of kid trying to toss a bowling ball. Secondly most of the ranged enemies int he game out range most of the tower making it near impossible to focus your attention elese where. The constant baby sitting of your towers is kind of counter-tower defense in my opinion.

Mobs - Spear chuckers toss spears for 3 miles away out ranging everything and thier spears appear to be armor penetrating as well. Orge's one shot pretty much everything from towers to heroes.

Hero's - Armed with weaksauce weapons, and slightly less damp toliet paper armor, they feel weak and borderline uselss against the bigger mobs you have to take on. No hero stats anymore like in DD1 where you could tune your gear to be DPS or Tower spec.

Maps - Made by someone who odviously likes playing hack and slash, and has no knowledge of tower defense games and choke points. Almost all the maps have no good defenseable choke points that some spear chucker or dragon cant just range down from afar.

Misc - This might just be me, or the game but it is extremely annoying that in order to choose a differnt difficulty range while playing with other people who are lvling up with you, that you have to leave and enter the starter tavern again, just to set the difficulty again.


4/10  - wait for free to play and pray they dont make it Pay to win.

Bottom line is, if you loved DD1, dont bother with DD2 unless you like feeling like your at a contant disadvantage.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Still a lot of work needs to be done, a lot of things to polish. But I was surprised when I found out that it's only pre-alpha. Gosh, great job. Wonder what awaits us next. On the whole, I'm glad to pay for early access, it's worth buying. Now I just hope that some of my friends will join me...

Overall, the game has changed it's every aspect. It has become different, though remained the same. The atmosphere is magical and charming. And gameplay is quite smooth, actually, both in terms of fps rate and the game process itself. And, what really is importmant to me, the interface is quite intuitive, though still leaves much to be desired. For example - I've set a mouse button for some ability, and on the icon of this ability it says: MouseThumbButton1. That's very cute, but it makes me cry, as I don't want to see THIS running over other icons...

But, I still strongly recommend this game. I just hope that offline component will be present in a while...

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Very fun game.  Few issues I hope are fixed:

1. half of the games you join the host is afk, when you go to join a new one you'll re-join the same one half the time. gets annoying.

2. after you win a match and everyone hit G, it goes to an overview screen that has an additional countdown that you can't skip - makes each game take longer for no reason.

3. no votekick

4. green mana seems a little too scarce each round - you're spending it all on repairs and not really able to expand on your towers much.

5. gear seems uninteresting.  I'm still wearing lvl 5 gear on my lvl 16 mage due to not finding anything better.

This is pre-alpha so i'm not complaining - so far i'm having a blast. Just wanted to note my main issues that I hope get addressed at some point.
voteText: 13 of 27 people (48%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is an addicting game formula, match up with people, grind for perfect loot Diablo-style until you want to cry.

As a tower defense game, it is lacking. It's more of a tower defense-lite. You can not select priority on your units, so your towers will likely focus on goblin fodder on the ground while a flying bomb passes overhead and goes straight for your objective.

The AI is a joke, many of your losses will be due to just straight up horrible AI.

This game is in one word; broken. I crash at least a dozen times a day, and that is not exclusive to my experience, this happens to everybody. Trendy refuses to acknowledge it. Instead they sweep it under the rug while they continue to release more content.

Trendy Entertainment as a studio is a total failure. This game is being begrudgingly birthed out of the UDK engine while Trendy Entertainment sits on live stream and straight up admits they have no idea what they're doing.

Recently Trendy Entertainment sued Ark development team for a whopping 40 million dollars, while I believe they were 100% justified legally, I fail to see how this money is being used to improve their game. Nothing has changed, this game is still cobbled together by misshapen, broken lego bricks. You'd think when a company makes more money in a suit then they have ever made in their entire existence that you'd see some sort of change.

All in all, I recommend this game, and I don't know why. I have 500+ hours and I will continue to play it. I really wish I could explain why I enjoy it, seeing as I spend most of the time playing being frustrated by how broken everything is, but I can't.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a fun game to play with friends and they give good rewards for coming back to play every day/week/month.

Pros:
+ Fun gameplay (Solo and with friends)
+ Defend the objective with a combination of towers and heros
+ Lots of builds and never enough inventory space to hold alternative sets
+ Very fun to try out new builds and perfect the placement of defenses on each map.
+ Monthly and daily quests. Hopefully soon weekly quests or tiered monthly quests as discussed on a recent blog.

Cons
- Slow development time for new features and small bug fixes.
- Gear resets have happen instead of limiting gear and then releasing better gear that make the OP gear obsolete.
- Leveling for new players is about 5x slower than it should be (my opinion).
- Pets are cool and fun but dont really do much to make them unique besides another piece of gear.
- Many of the in game purchases are a waste. For exapmple, some pets you can only get from spending $$$ and then you often get a common quality one. No one keeps those and they should be legendary if you are going to spend the money on it. See the comment above where pets dont really give you a big bonus from pet to pet anyway. Just make it Legendary for the 5% extra stats or whatever it is imo.

This game is worth giving it 20 minutes and making your own decision from there. All you have to do is download it and click play.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nFeels very familiar with the first game.. Build towers, upgrade towers, kill waves and waves of enemies to win. reviewText:
Early Access Review

Hm nope.


This is a more rigid and microtransactioned version of Dungeon defenders 1. Gameplay feels stiff, unintuitive and bland. You KNOW anything interesting won't be free, and that is ok, I mean Dungeon Defenders 1 wasn't free, but I got all DLC and everything for 10$. Just extra inventory space alone in this game costs three times as much, and you're still stuck with uncustomizable and limited characters. (Unless you buy more and find or buy whatever costume peices make the stiff characters look different.)

I'm glad I tried without paying, but just watch and see how high this paywall goes for anything bland none the less remarkable.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So it seems a lot of the recent negative reviews are because these guys are sueing someone from the Ark development team and people are butthurt over it because ARK might shut down. As someone who played and enjoyed a lot of ARK, I can say if someone breaks the law then someone breaks the law. Its the developers fault for not checking contracts.

That being said, the game is fine. If you liked DD1 you will like DD2, plain and simple. Its a third person tower defense with farming and character deveopment. Just like the first one. They are adding a bunch of content and seem to do regular fixes for the game.

It's free to play so try the game for yourself and try not to listen to people who are only ruining the games credit because of something they cannot comprehend.

Contracts are contracts. The law is the law.

P.S. I have WAY more hours in ARK than DD2 so I'm not just some fanboy douching out over my favouritest game in the whole wide world, I'm giving an objective opinion based on the facts.

Have a nice day!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I got hooked into DD1 after playing the first mission. After I finished the game and modded the crap out of it, I played dungeon defenders eternity and fell in love with it all over again.

This sorry excuse for a dungeon defenders game is just that. A sorry excuse. The graphics may be 'nicer' (I personally prefer the look the old games had), and it may be less prone to awkward crashes, but damn. At the very least, DDE had some half/decent gameplay to go along with it.

Back to my point about being hooked at the first mission. I played through the tutorial level as the sorceror (which was my go to character considering how the summoner was yet to be implemented) and after putting up with the crappy enemy spawn times, the crappier enemy walking pace and the even crappier enemy damage (despite not having any armour at all), I uninstalled it and am glad it's no longer taking up space on my SSD. I did head back to the hub world, but got lost as to what I was doing. The UI was wonky and difficult to navigate, the new systems failed to improve the solid old ones and there was basically no point to having such a massive scale revamp.

It makes me even angrier that my favourite hero from DD1/DDE, The Summoner, had the one gimik that made his character interesting and different from the rest removed. In DD1/DDE, The Summoner had the ability to summon crystal versions of the enemies in place of towers. These crystal enemies has the ability to move and even chase enemies. Despite the AI for your minions being wonky and just plain broken at times, the gimik changed the flow of gameplay and allowed for such a dynamic sense of strategy. Suddenly, if my tower went down and I had no mana to replace it, I could choose to relocate some of my other minions to it's job. This was such a cool and different mechanic, and I loved it the instant I started using it.

NOW, The Summoner (as of the writing of this review) has had his best quality removed. All his towers function like towers and blockades, which is a huge let down and a shame. On top of that, he lost his other two great abilities which allowed easy surveying of the battlefield, namely his Phase Shift Overlord" ability
date: which turned the classic 3rd/1st person perspective into a top-down look of the entire battlefield. He could even summon and move minions from this perspective
recommended: once again adding to the extra gameplay elements. But NOPE
hoursPlayed: Trendy thought it would be a good idea to remove the interesting mechanics they had set up in the previous games.\n\nTrendy
voteText: get your act together. I'm happy that you're not actually charging anyone to trial what is essentially a shiny pile of garbage compared to your previous works
helpfulPercent: but seriously. What happen to the old magic
votesHelpful: that made DD1/DDE so good?"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First off this game is in alpha. This means that the game still has issues and isn't feature complete.

TL;DR The game has a few issues but is still quite good.

I have enjoyed this game so far it has many features I enjoy more than Dungeon Defenders 1.

The gathering mana system has greatly improved. Instead of going around to all the chests on the map you just have to interact with one. The other thing about the mana system that is a huge improvement is that you don't lose mana when you pick up a large chunk for example, if you only have space for 5 mana left and you picked up 10 in DD1 you would lose 5 mana in DD2 you gain 5 mana and 5 mana drops on your player. The only issue I have is with dropping mana, you can only drop 10 at a time and there is no drop all mana button.

The sub-core system is fantastic in my opinion. You can easily just build up around your main cores and deal with extra mobs released from destroyed sub-cores or you can spread your defenses out more, take that risk and the payout is a fair bit more exp.

The skill / tower build system now gives you four options instead of five. This is both a pro and a con to me. The fewer skills and fewer towers you have, the more balanced the game will be. This is because it will be that much simpler to balance, but on the other hand that extra skill or extra tower would be nice. The placement system for some of the monk's auras are slightly aggravating. If you build the monk's auras first you can then place traps or towers quite close to then, however if you build traps or towers first then you can't place the auora in the same spot as if you did the order the other way around. On a side note all the towers look quite nice.

Mob pathing seems to be fairly good. I have had a few issues where mobs get stuck behind the spawner wall and have had to use skills to kill them. I get the occasional mob stuck on a wall but as the game development progresses I am finding this to be less and less of an issue. Also flying kobolds are ♥♥♥ holes.

The maps are pretty exciting. They look quite nice and every map has it's environmental traps. The environmental traps can also be activated from a player shooting at it which is nice for when you can't get over there in time but there have been a few times when a stray shot has activated it. The maps are also where the game shows being in alpha a little bit. There are still a few ways to get outside of some of the maps, but as of the latest patch (November 21 2014) many of those have been fixed.

Solo play versus group play is a huge difference. The ideal way to play this game is with a party of four. This is due to the item drop system giving higher chances to parties with more people in it.

The game still lacks a trade system that makes me sad, but it looks like it's coming. There are references to it in the config files for the game.

I know there is content missing and I am looking forward to seeing how the game development progresses.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First of all, I understand this is pre-alpha and a lot of the things I dislike about it might be fixed. However I don't think that will change how I feel about the game, and here's why.

I played DD1, and there are a lot of similarities. The problem is there's nothing new and exciting enough to draw me to playing DD2 instead of DD1. The four main classes are all basically the same with a few differences, but nothing has changed in their mechanics or the way you play them.

Combos between towers show a lot of promise, but that alone isn't enough. All this work for building a new game seems like a waste of time to me if it's basically the same game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

BOYCOTT TRENDY, BOYCOTT F2P, BOYCOTT MICROTRANSACTIONS BOYCOTT EARLY ACCESS!!

am so glad that I spent my hard earned money on a game that they didn't tell you up front was going to be f2p, and micro-transaction based. Should I have researched it a little more before I bought into it? Maybe but they had the repuation with the first game, and I figured they had the understanding that they had a good community behind them. Why charge me for early access when you just plan on releasing it free? Is that the thanks I get to help test your new crap business model? Thanks alot Trendy, you guys really made some moves to drag your name through crap. I no longer can recommend this game anymore than I recommend the first one. Once you guys pull your heads out of your rear, charge for a game that you worked hard on, instead of peddling it early access style, only to release it f2p with microtransactions, which obviously will just allow you to make it pay to win, or whatever stupid crap you guys are doing now. After all you guys are trying to turn a succesful tower defense game with a great community backing you up into a crap MOBA, great work, you really did a fine job alienating every one of your original followers.

TL;DR If you love the first game, stick with it, but I can't recommend this game, or any other game that they release, as they basically ripped everyone off. Sorry guys, this game cannot be salvaged, they have destroyed the dungeon defenders name.

Early Access Review

I played both this game and the first one for a fairly short time each.  The gameplay got old for me fairly quickly, but it seemed to be a game that could be a decent time killer and could maybe grow in scope.

However, with the recent actions of the developers of this game with regards to what it regards as it's competition, I can honestly say that I will in no way support anything that they put out, and I encourage others to do the same.  If they are worried that another game is providing too much competition, they should focus on improving their own game instead of tearing down another.  Bad show, Trendy.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Pay To Win game. The best deal is $100 for 12,500 Gems. You convert gems into items in this game. To get a pass into the Dragonfall Carnival for a chance at Epic Items you need to pay 150 gems. This game used to be okay but after it went the route of PTW, it lost any chance to be a great game. Pity.

PROS
1. Campaign
There are 16 levels for you to play, ranging from Level 1 to Level 40 (Max).

2. Dragonfall City
The Tavern, the Personal Room, the City, the Catapults and all the Merchants make the game look great.

CONS
1. Pay To Win
You can pay cash to get Legendary items ahead of other players. PTW just spoils the game.

2. Spin The Wheel for Items
This is a PTW mechanic. You either use 10 tickets that come from drops or spend Gems.

3. Low Player Count
For a 4-player game, there are really few players.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First off, I love this game, and it's constantly being updated to become just as addicting as its predecessor.

Genre:  Tower defence with loot finder elements.

Pros:

(- Level up system:
* Ability points.
*  Different towers.
*  Stat increases.
*  Gear level Requirments.)
- The combined genre of TD (Tower defence) and Loot Finder make this game extremely unique.
- Up to 4 player coop which might be increased to 6 or 8 player on select maps in the future.
- Great graphics.
- Four different hero classes.  Some might complain about this in comparison to DD1, but again, there will be more hero classes in the future.


Neutral:
- Non boostable leveling.  This is something that I can't quite tell if I like or not.  Allow me to exaplain...
- In the first game, if you wanted to level up a character very quickly it could be done easily by setting up a defence with multiple high level heros and then switching to your level one to instantly hit around level 70 after maybe 4 waves, depending on your setup.  In DD2 this is not possible, your character level is capped with a maximum level difference between both characters of 5.

Cons:  Last time I played the game was still in Pre-Alpha, might be in Alpha now, and these cons will repesent the game in Pre-Alpha.

- No kicking system.  Nothing grinds my gears more than when someone ques up for coop and afks.
- No Pets.  I miss my treadmill buddies.  Maybe we'll get some elliptical pals this time around.
- No survival mode as of yet, I'm sure they'll get around to it soon though.
- No outfits yet, not much of a con.

It's very difficult to think of cons for this game.

Eventual pro:
The game will eventually become free to play with microtransactions for cosmetic overrides.  If you buy it now you'll recieve in game credit for what you paid!

I highly recommend this game.  I love it.
Recommend buying with friends!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First of all, I played about 600 hours in DD1, I dont really think that DD2 can be even REMOTELY as good as DD1 now (even with the fact that 99% of good gear is duped/hacked).

Very laggy, crashed after 1 hour of staying in tavern because it ate all my memory (16 gb). Game servers is laggy too, interface is non-convinient. Didnt had any chance to test gameplay in-deep because it eats all my memory and crashes. Also vsync not working. Uninstalled. 0/10 atm.

Oh, did I mention that this game is absolutely P2W?

I mean F.UСК free to play P2W garbage games, which DD2 is right now. Stash space for money? Additional character slots? Seriously? This is just what I able to see by the time I was wandering around tavern and playing first map for a bit, but I guess since there is some kind of gems currency which you can buy - game is complete p2w garbage. Devs say you can only buy cosmetics with it, at the same time game wants your money for char slots and stash space.

Tower balance looks pretty poor at least on squire. In DD1 you could put, as I remember, 3 harpoons on starting map from all chests you got at first level (4+1 chests that give you 40 mana each and harpoon worth 80 I think). Here I just spammed some tower around crystal, I had enough mana to build like 8 towers on first level before first wave. Towers feel less important because of that, you just spam them everywhere because you cant even upgrade them before level 4.

Map selection screen looks poorly made with really crappy models and overall worse than DD1's simple and good looking level interface.

No option to cancel this really annoying squire attack-step animation.

Tab key cant be rebinded (i guess its a console or something). Fix this please.

Some weird chests appeared at the end of first mission which took about 10 seconds to appear in unskippable cutscene, then it took me a while to find a little area where I could press E to open middle chest (and why there is two gray chests around it?) and it dropped some loots. Well, easy to fix this, right?

I have no idea why it gets so many positive rewiers, I guess people see that its free to play and happy about it, it also brings a lot of new people to the game. Thrust me, DD1 is amazing atmospheric game, nothing in tower defence genre will ever be even remotely close as good as it is. Endgame has its problems, hacking is a big problem, but still.

I just dream of DD1 reset with new VAC system and some kind of auction house, couple of new maps and achievements, option to make graphics not so anime-like - bam, perfect all-time TD game.
