Tower balance looks pretty poor at least on squire. In DD1 you could put, as I remember, 3 harpoons on starting map from all chests you got at first level (4+1 chests that give you 40 mana each and harpoon worth 80 I think). Here I just spammed some tower around crystal, I had enough mana to build like 8 towers on first level before first wave. Towers feel less important because of that, you just spam them everywhere because you cant even upgrade them before level 4.

Map selection screen looks poorly made with really crappy models and overall worse than DD1's simple and good looking level interface.

No option to cancel this really annoying squire attack-step animation.

Tab key cant be rebinded (i guess its a console or something). Fix this please.

Some weird chests appeared at the end of first mission which took about 10 seconds to appear in unskippable cutscene, then it took me a while to find a little area where I could press E to open middle chest (and why there is two gray chests around it?) and it dropped some loots. Well, easy to fix this, right?

I have no idea why it gets so many positive rewiers, I guess people see that its free to play and happy about it, it also brings a lot of new people to the game. Thrust me, DD1 is amazing atmospheric game, nothing in tower defence genre will ever be even remotely close as good as it is. Endgame has its problems, hacking is a big problem, but still.

I just dream of DD1 reset with new VAC system and some kind of auction house, couple of new maps and achievements, option to make graphics not so anime-like - bam, perfect all-time TD game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Please note: This is a first impressions review of the current pre-alpha build as of the 8th of December 2014. This is  NOT  an in-depth review and I'd just like to address my experience compared to other reviewers.

Okay so, the first thing I want to address is the difficulty of the game. I've noticed a few reviewers talking about the difficulty of the game when it comes to playing solo. I myself enjoyed Dungeon Defenders 1 alone and rarely went online (partly due to the amount of hackers, but that's besides the point), so obviously I would be spending a vast majority of my time on this game offline or with a select group of friends, meaning if the game is much too hard for one person, I wouldn't be playing this game much at all, nor would I like it to be quite frank. However, as you can see, I've given this early access game a thumbs up. Why? Because it's not as hard in single player as others may believe. The entire game actually feels much easier overall compared to the original dungeon defenders.

The mechanic that stands out as to why it's easier, is that  you no longer have to stand next to your towers and wait to repair or upgrade them.  While it's true you still need to be close to the towers to begin the process of repairing or upgrading them, you still move freely, and can carry on fighting enemies or go elsewhere on the map while it's repairing. A little bar on the side of your crosshair shows you the progress of the repair/upgrade so you're still conscious of your tower in the meantime. You can only upgrade or repair one tower at a time, like in the original dungeon defenders, but the fact you can no guard the tower yourself while it's repairing for example, ends up helping you in the longrun. Personally, this is a very welcome change to the core game as it feels like I'm now doing more than just running around the map repairing my towers; It's more of an incentive to fight yourself.

Just to let any readers know, I've tried out all four of the heroes ALONE and had little trouble beating the first few maps with each of them WITHOUT grinding for experience to level up nor switching between heroes mid-game. I'll admit, the huntress is a little hard to play solo as she uses traps, but as they're so small and use little mana, you can place many of them around before filling out the max tower limit. The Monk is clearly made to play as part of a team seeing as it has health and tower boosts, but he can still very well stand his own ground alongside his defenses. Oddly enough, the Squire and the Apprentice felt very similar, as their first two towers are ranged projectile defenses and barricades. When playing as either of them, by the time I got to the final wave, I could (and did, to prove it to myself) sit back and watch as my towers did all the work. In my opinion, that doesn't make playing as them easy"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So far its ok, its not dungeon defenders 1 or anything, but its alright. Seeing as how its going to be free to play, I don't recommend paying for it unless you actually plan on influencing the game. I would much rather a game be a one time purchase and have a good game, rather then having in game shortcuts for real world money. They say they wont have anything in the shop that will effect the game, but I don't see that lasting long.

Talking about the game now, the graphics got a major boost. Very pretty, and you don't need a massive build for your pc to play on max. The simplified skills and tower building is nice, as is the fact that upgrades are all one unified price.


As far as the forseeable issues... Crafting has taken a massive hit in the quality department, you used to just put mana into an item and choose a stat to boost, and mana as a currency has been removed, its now just gold coins, which is kinda dumb, and instead of the innkeeper selling you a selection of 3 items, the innkeeper is who you report bugs to, and you buy armor from some guy, and your trinkets from some other guy... now to upgrade items you just combine things till you can make a stat SLIGHTLY better... its not really worth upgradeing gear till end game.

Haven't figured out how to change my character, or if i can even do that...haven't really looked into it, so I could just be being dumb...

As far as difficulty goes, they made it harder by making your towers far less effective, and make the enemies drop way less mana for your towers. They added a personal mana bar for your spells and abilities, so that was nice, instead of making you waste upgrades for towers on your spells.

Completely lost my train of thought just now, so I leave you all with what I have written.


Tl;Dr Its not as good as DD1, but will be worth playing when its free.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Played the game a bit already, 40hrs+, I like it. I personally played DD1 quite a lot.

About DD2:

Pros:
F2P (Free To Play), with NO P2W (Pay to Win), Only Pay to boost, making life a lot easier, such as extra bags, more character slots and cosmetics, Defenders pack is worth it, and if you bought this a lot earlier you probably got some extra bags from that.  (I dunno if they will change this view)

Less towers, Less characters than DD1, Making life simplier than DD1 end game, which was basically 1 misplace and you got ruined...

If you played DD1, and you liked it, then I highly recomend it.

Very short Bugged Enemy Timer compared to DD1 which had like 10 minutes.... Yes that's a PRO!

Cons

EXTREMELY limited build options at start of end game (NM1-NM2), requires specific gear, they are currently balancing drop rates, but I think the build options should be required at the end stage of Game rather than start of End Game

Grinding, If you don't like it. I recomend you go away....

Very small inventory space, in DD1 you had an entire Tavern to fill, Gems must be used to get more inventory sadly, I think its a con. but hey, at least you get to a F2P game.

Laggy as hell sometimes {Doesn't matter computer}, please note that they state the game is in alpha, although the game content is like DD1 when they first released it, it has enough content to make you spend several hundreds of hours for grinding, but for just campaign? then no don't buy it.

Would I recomend?
Do you like Tower Defense in 3rd person?
Do you like to DPS?
Do you like to Grind?
Do you like to Grind even more?
Are you a grind-a-holic?
Did you like Dungeon Defenders 1 (Or Eternity)
Do you like Sanctum but wanted more of a fantasy setting?
are you a Unreal Engine lover? (I think DD2 is unreal engine, at least DD1 was)

If you answered yes to any of the questions... then YES II RECOMEND IT!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I personally have not played the first Dungeon Defenders game, but I put a ton of hours into Dungeon Defenders Eternity, and saying I enjoyed the experience is an understatement. For something in Pre-Alpha, the amount of development that has happened in this game is extremely exceptional. What you get out of the game depends on what you put into it, and to be perfectly honest, I feel like I have put a decent amount into it.

Compared to Dungeon Defenders Eternity, this game offers a variety of ways to play, since one aspect I particular enjoy is the synergy that certain defenses can undergo with one another. To name a few, There is the Geyser/Storm Combo, which can keep certain targets in place (some argue the combo is broken, but I could not care less on that point), and another combo is something I call Magic Shatter (people may call it something else) where you freeze a target, then send it airborne. The result is when they come back down, the target shatters, most of the time instantly killing it. The point is unlike in DDE, The defenses all seem to have a particular place, and do not seem to make any single tower worthless. (except for maybe the Squire's Training Dummy)

The gear in Dungeon Defenders 2 is already extremely versatile , with unique abilities to a certain item type that can greatly improve a player's performance, meanwhile in DDE, gear just improved tower and player stats directly. An example of some gear affixes are improving a specific tower performance, such as Increased Flameburst Tower damage by 5.03%" making the item effectively an apprentice ideal item to improve his flameburst tower damage. This allows items to cater to specific classes
date: and once again improving the depth of the tower and also the character. There are some rarer mods that are extremely significant
recommended: so if you want to get truly powerful items
hoursPlayed: you have to be ready to hunt for them to get the best performance. Another thing I believe is improved compare to DDE is that gear is still able to be leveled
voteText: but leveling gear does not break the game as hard as it did in DDE. When you upgrade items
helpfulPercent: the stats will go up by a fixed amount every time
votesHelpful: unlike in DDE
votesTotal:
where the amount that the stat will increase is dependent on the stats the item had when it spawned.


The next thing I will address is the leveling system. The leveling system itself is pretty straight forward
votesFunny: you get experience by completing waves and defeating enemies
commentsCount: as well as completing certain conditions to gain fixed experience points and gold. That is pretty standard
column16: but it's a good system. The thing that I believe that DD2 has done amazingly is that instead of being able to allocate points to character and tower stats directly as a result of leveling up
column17: the character and tower stats go up automatically
column18: and once you reach level 5
column19: you gain 2 points that you can put into passive skills to improve your characters performance in a series of ways. For example
column20: the Squire is able to place points into an ability that gives his spike barricades a chance to stun enemies when they attack targets. The more points you put into a skill
column21: the more effective it becomes. As you put more points in
column22: the results will have diminishing returns
column23: so a player can decide when enough is enough
column24: and begin skilling other abilities. Furthermore
column25: you can completely respec your skills for free at any time
column26: so long as you are not in the middle of a wave
column27:
allowing you to test out various builds and find a setup that suits you. Each character has 6 skills you can invest in.


The next thing I will address is the enemies. A few of the classic enemies make their return
column31: etc. The enemies still come from a variety of spawn points
column32: where a variety of enemies will come out of each one. Those enemies were great in DDE
column33: and most of them return in DD2. The enemy cast also expands
column34: offering new challenges to overcome. One particular subject that has received mixed criticism is that some enemies have the ability to attack towers from outside of the common tower's attack ranges. This makes the game a bit more of a puzzle
column35: due to the fact that unlike in DDE
column36: tower ranges can't be increased to such an obscene level to counter absolutely everything that the map may throw at you. This does not break the game
column37: there are still measures that the player can take to manage the various enemies
column38: both old and new.\n\nThe final subject I will touch on is the Co-op play. I never went to public taverns and went looking for people to play with
column39: so I won't comment too much on public matchmaking
column40: but I have friends I have played with
column41: and this game is just as awesome in Co-op as it is in solo play. If you have friends that you know and can communicate with
column42: the experience is far more satisfying. The enemies will scale with the number of party numbers
column43: both in health and overall difficulty
column44: making it a perfect game to either play solo
column45:
or bring in some of your friends to go beat down the Old One's armies.


To conclude
column46: for a game in its Pre-Alpha state
column47: I believe this game is exceptional
column48: and will go far. The devs are working to update the game
column50: and working to balance the game. Some things in the game still need fixing
column51: some things still need to be balanced
column52: but the game is still very young
column53: and I am certain it will develop into a memorable classic. It will turn into a F2P at launch
column55: I don't mind having paid for the game. I'm actually glad to have paid
column56: because it's a way people can say "thank you" to the creators
column57: especially since the game will be free at launch unless something changes that. In a nutshell
column58: if you enjoyed the first Dungeon Defenders
column59: I would assume you would enjoy DD2
column60: the same holds true for Dungeon Defenders Eternity."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Big improvements on the first Dungeon Defenders, Fun game to play alone or with friends. And it can be as challanging as you want.

It is a free game which makes friends try out the game more appealing.

Also, Its not paytowin or anything like that, you can grind out free skins  by doing daily and montlhy quests.
Lacks a bit of endgame once you hit level cap, gets grindy too. but thats doesnt mean its a bad thing.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Fantastic game, certainly at this barely left alpha stage.
The game is complete, you can enjoy everything with the occasional bug or glitch.

Can the game be better? Offcourse it could be so much better, but let's remember they are still working on it.
Can you compare the game to DD1? Partly, and that is what frustrates the DD1 players. You have to look at this as another game enterily.
Can you play the game without spending real cash? yes you can enjoy everything playwise, you can buy costumes which cost tons of money. And with the carnival update you can buy" older monthly pets
recommended: well you buy tickets for the carnival game
hoursPlayed: and you have fixed rewards which include bearkira.\nDid I buy gems
voteText: yes
helpfulPercent: as I enjoyed the game very much and I want to support the creators.\nDo I hope the game evolves and get's better? Yes very much
votesHelpful: and I'll be playing/following this game closely.\nBefore this game I was an avid mmorpg lover
votesTotal:
but all the mmorpg are just bland and boring.
This is a mix between tower defense and rpg and I love that part as it keeps making to come back.

I have high expectations for the game.

So if you like tower defense games with a few rpg elements
votesFunny: this might be it.\n\nEnjoy it
commentsCount: as it is free\n"

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nLacks what I expected, bought near the beginning of it's release. A few short months later, I was left with a free game that I wouldn't enjoy touching on, with only 4 hours I don't have a majority when it comes to hours yet I feel the game needs more to fit what I expect. With it being free I can see people playing the game as it fits a titles like this, yet it doesn't compare to the greatness I experienced from it's predecesor. - Pengz ;[
